...I suppose you're right. Perhaps I'm too used to practicality thanks to piloting.
...In a sense, yes, that's still doing something. I've tried to avoid being too sentimental... broken equipment is dead weight for pirates.
A life of piracy will cause you to judge machines on their function. But you're right...a memento is meaningful.
...It's the least I can do. I have some other things as well--a music box, and a sample from their laboratories. But those don't frighten recruits as much.
...They didn't leave behind much else. New recruits usually stare at it for a while...I don't show them the other heirlooms I have.
Most girls join our crew with few possessions. I myself only had that eyepiece and a few other things...it tends to intimidate rookies.
...It's the only memento I wear around and show others. It helps identify me as "the scary girl with the thing on her face."
"Mother"? Oh, right...like a Fama. That sounds nice...I'm glad you have something to remember her by.
...A "mother" is the woman who carried you, correct? With a male parent...I'm glad you could bond with her.
...Right. You have "mothers" and "fathers" here insteads of Omas and Famas. In any case, I'm glad you cherish that.
"Mother"...like a Fama, if I remember correctly. I wish I'd spent more time making things with my parents...
Competing isn't meant to be fun. I'm overcoming an obstacle--forced exposure on an unfamiliar planet.
I don't see the fun in competitions like this. I do see a springboard for self-improvement, win or lose.
Fun is found in pastimes, not competitions. A picnic, for example...or any time shared with loved ones.
When I picture a fun time, I think of relaxing in a spa--something with no winners, losers, or failure. A game is meant to expose your weaknesses.
...There's no danger for an Earth woman. Our crew is a known target of this planet.
No danger to you, maybe. My job demands constant vigilance, especially on an aggressor like Earth.
...Yuelia, part of my role as officer is to patrol and scout ahead for danger. And Earth has attempted to kill us before.
As long as I'm here on Earth, danger is always present. I do enough scouting for their attack fleets when we're lightyears away.
I don't like how luck-based this form of poker is. There's no betting to make things interesting...but I can still try to read each of you.
It's true that the primary strategy here seems to be "wear more clothing." Still, I can reflect upon whether I judged my opponents correctly.
Even in a dogfight, there is an element of luck. It's far too high here, I agree...but I can still make predictions based on body language.
I agree, Yuelia... especially since there's no betting. But even if reading my opponents isn't much help here, I can still practice doing so.
There are more pressing matters than my naked body, and I must remain positive around them, too, for the sake of my pilots.
...Well, part of my job is maintaining a positive outlook in the face of an enemy fleet--or at least making sure others do so.
"Collected" may be a better word. If I can't keep my composure when naked, I can't keep my pilots calm on a mission.
The other crew members see me naked all the time. Besides, nudity is no issue next to a raid in terms of morale.
...The image of confidence is one of a leader's most important qualities.
...A leader has to project confidence, even if she isn't sure what to do.
...Confidence is more a tool than a state of mind. It is meant to keep your subordinates calm.
...I'm quite practiced at appearing that way. Confidence is to reassure others, not yourself.
...One at a time, Amy. Those are all complicated questions.
...I appreciate your curiosity, but none of those are simple topics. Please focus.
...Slow down. Each of those would require some explanation.
...Which of those are you most curious about? We can start there.
...The more decisions a woman makes, the more her appearance reflects them. Life imitates art, I suppose.
It's not so strange an idea. Our choices in life will go to inform our appearances, much like a character in a book.
...My hair color may be a coincidence, but past decisions will determine how a woman dresses and carries herself. It makes sense.
Fiction comes from observing real-life women. Poise, posture, dress...none of those things come separate from our personalities and pasts.
Perhaps Earth's resources were more scarce than I'd realized. What are you lacking? Do you not have cotton or synthetic fibers?
What are your complaints with your underwear, Amy? Even simple cotton bras and panties should suffice for a civilian.
All I wear underneath is supportive training gear. Maybe basic underwear is a luxury on Earth...what does yours not provide, Amy?
I've never had a desire for more "advanced" underwear. Mine is supportive, and other kinds are to be attractive...what are you looking for?
..."Dykes"? You've now used two words I haven't understood...
...Which is it, "dykes" or "lesbos"? I'm not familiar with either...
...First "lesbos," now "dykes." Young girls lack perspective on what others understand...
...I thought your issue was with "lesbos," Mary. Now you've switched to "dykes."
...So, you'd only wear skintight clothing as an underlayer. I'd heard Earth women were more conservative...is it because of men's presence?
...Is it part of Earth culture to not expose your figure, even in spandex? Perhaps to avoid tempting men...
...So you would wear skintight shorts, but never by themselves. Is Earth women's extra layering a defense measure against men?
...I suppose with how aggressive men can be, Earth women hide their bodies. Your shorts would suffice on Mejare without any layers over them.
...If you could explain what "ECHO" technology is used for, I would appreciate it.
...I haven't heard of "ECHO" technology. Are they wearable scanning devices?
...This isn't the technology you're thinking of...we don't have anything called an "ECHO." What is it?
My parents put a stop to me doing anything too dangerous...while they were around. I fended for myself on the streets after that.
...Once I came home with some bruises, my parents put a tighter leash on me. Once they were gone, I learned how to fight just fine.
...It started as typical teenage interest, but my parents quashed it when I started fighting. Then they weren't around for that...and I kept fighting.
...On top of the danger, it ruined the cutesy image of me my parents had marketed themselves on. But once I was alone, it was me and my fists.
...That doesn't surprise me. In my experience, Earth views many of its colonies as "unnatural."
...Mejare and Tarak represent the ultimate breakdown in communication between men and women. Still, there's more to relationships than sharing a sex.
I suppose I have no place to talk when it comes to understanding men, nor does any Mejarian. But if they're really human like you and me, then it must be possible.
I knew men don't have uteri--our male doctor was apparently baffled when he first scanned one. But I figured those egglike sperm-holders had cycles...
I knew men don't carry their children, but they have those dangling sphere-organs that hold sperm. I assumed it'd function like a uterus wall...
...Men have those round ball-like organs hanging near their rods, don't they? If they hold sperm, I assumed they'd behave like the organs that hold our eggs...
See, it's off already...I think the armor you're used to may be archaic.
No, I can get it off with no issue...maybe you could show me some of yours.
It's made of a rather light shock-absorbent material, actually...perhaps you wear the metal armor I've read about.
I've read that women on Earth used to don metal armor. That sounds more like the impractical plating you're describing...
...Mejare as a colony is only about 100 years old. Even if that were enough time to speciate, the planet is terraformed--there's no pressure to do so.
A few generations on a terraformed planet like Mejare is neither enough time nor the proper environment to cause us to evolve into a different species.
...You have the right idea, yes. Incidentally, it's good to see that you're still alive...I wasn't sure you'd be.
...Yes, Mejarian sex is rather intimate. I'm glad to see you've continued your piracy without any injuries...
...I've recently learned that to be the case, thanks to our male prisoners...
...That's true. There are men I've come to respect...the prisoners aboard our ship.
...I was certainly taught men were all the same, and less than human at that. I know that's not true, thanks to the men we captured...
...Is that so? Who are these colleagues of yours, and how do they hide it?
...I know men aren't all the same. I was taught that you were, but when I first saw one in person, part of me knew you were human...
...I used to maintain that men were savage animals, like everyone on my homeworld. Still, seeing one in person on my first raid...he had a human face.
...I'm aware now that men are as human as women are. Deep down, I think any Mejarian who sees a man in person realizes that...
...I imagine a man carrying a rocket launcher would avoid fighting at close range.
...You seem perfectly fit for a man, Brock. Though I suppose wielding explosives would encourage you to fight at a distance...
...I'm still not sure why I would want to a be a brawler. Are you saying you fight for a living?
Much like how we're not to fire missiles at close range...are you a pirate, as well? Why are you in firefights?
...I'm sure you have last resorts at close range. But I'm part of a pirate group...why are you always fighting?
...You're correct. A missile's power comes with the danger of using it up close...I'm sure you're familiar.
...Yes. Dread pilots face a similar issue with our bombs if the enemy is too close...it's good you understand that.
...There must be some respected status among men known as a "brawler." I'm not familiar...
...You sound very complimentary, but I'm not familiar with why being a "brawler" is so valued in a man's eyes.
...I'm not accustomed to male culture. I understand you enjoy tests of physical strength...is that why you respect me as a "brawler"?
...I didn't claim to be proud of my streetfights. Is "Brawling" some kind of rite of passage in male culture?
...I know it's lowbrow. I had to face that when I started fights with crew members...is "Brawling" some specific men's activity I don't know about?
...I've heard that men enjoy fighting each other for sport. You sound excited that I might "brawl"...but it's not something a woman values.
...I suppose this is where men and women differ. A man might be proud of his time streetfighting, but it's quite degrading in a woman's eyes...
...I suppose Max can be a girl's name, as well. A woman wearing a bodysuit makes more sense...though I'm now trying to picture a man in one.
...It's good to hear you have female colleagues...it's good to know that they're the ones in bodysuits. Though I'm curious if a man could pull one off.
My mistake. At least you get along with women on this planet...you donning a skintight suit would probably amuse her.
Hm. I might like to meet this woman you know, then...we share a fashion sense. She'd probably laugh if you stuffed yourself into a suit like hers...
...Perhaps I should've realized that. I need to remind myself that men and women live together here...
...My apologies. I'm not used to men who have female colleagues... even on a planet full of them.
...A man, I assume. I suppose men and women's names may have become frozen on my homeworld, but continued to evolve on Earth...
A female Max, and a male Sandy...I shouldn't expect names to be gendered the same on Earth. Is "Meia" a female name here?
...I wouldn't know how to seduce a man. And if I did, my goal would not be to stuff you into my flightsuit...
...It would be a challenge for me to seduce a man when I don't know what you like. And I'm not interested in seeing you stretch my suit out.
I suppose one could tailor a suit to fit a man's body. It'd need broader shoulders, wider sleeves and legs...a smaller butt.
I see...Max is a girl's name on Earth. Lasers and tight suits are standard aesthetics for a Mejarian...but what does she use to run?
I see. Mejarian women, too, value lasers and tight clothing...and speed. But in flight, not running.
Is that so? My Dread is respected as the fastest in our fleet. What technology is this that she uses to run so quickly?
On the ground, perhaps. No one outpaces my ship. Technology to run fast is new to me--how does it work?
...I'm not sure what you mean, Shamir. "Those that slither"...?
...I may be inclined to forgive you if I understood the comparison, Shamir...
...You may have a skewed impression of what a healthy blood sugar is. Self-starvation does not lead to muscle gain.
...I don't tell them to starve themselves--not that it would make them fit regardless. Don't frame your eating habits as typical.
...I suppose, if your goal is to delude yourself and those attempting to help you.
...The doctor would probably notice that she weighs less, as well. If you're not interested in really losing weight, why bother seeing her?
...If you're not seeing results, then perhaps you could describe your current exercise routine.
...What do you for your exercise regimen? If it isn't structured, then no wonder it isn't working.
Many of our fresh recruits would agree with you. I ensure they follow my orders, and the reality of dogfighting does the rest.
We tend to recruit girls who have problems with authority. They also think I'm condescending until their first raid.
To disgruntled young women off the streets, sternness can indeed seem like condescension. It takes a raid for them to understand.
...So you are still fighting. Meanwhile, my pilots look to me for a cool head in battle...even as my breasts come out.
...So even as a singer, the need for violence remains. A Dread team leader's role is precisely to not be excited during battle...
...Yes. To delay doing so would draw attention to them.
...That is my intention, yes. To start with my smallest item...
...Yes. It makes the most sense to do so...at least with no context.
...Yes, size generally determines what women will strip first. Even if it's unusual...
...Men, you mean? Yes, I'd agree--the men I know have a habit of involving themselves in my business.
...Men are? I can vouch for that--our doctor tries to give me advice, our helmsman tries to chat, and our mech pilot combines with my Dread.
...I don't care for nosy people. If you mean men, then I agree--the man in my squadron goes as far as intruding into my cockpit when we combine ships.
...Men are nosy? Well, forming a Vandread with a man means I'm stuck in my cockpit with him, so I'm inclined to agree...
Men are a nosy, intrusive people. I know three of them, and they're all nosy... imagine how I feel knowing each has saved my life.
I'm afraid that's not true at the moment...Earth is convinced they are the only "true" humans, and they see other human settlements as resource farms.
I also hope that one day human settlements across the galaxy will be preserved. Unfortunately, Earth is currently ransacking them to preserve itself.
...If it comforts you, Mejare's all-female society is hardly a utopia. Still, men's presence seems much more jarring.
I'm sure you could become accustomed to it--it is nice to share anatomy with everyone around you.
I have an equally hard time picturing life when half the population is larger than me, with dangling appendages between their legs...
Men's absence leads to a much simpler understanding of what it means to be a human, if you ask me. I'm sure you can relate to other women better.
Even if you're used to men being around, surely you must understand other women more easily. You'd grow accustomed to Mejare.
...Well, you're not my subordinate. Nor would I get much information by barking orders at you.
I'd like to think I'm above the standard of abusive prison guards. I'm here to socialize, after all.
"Boring" is a very mild insult. New recruits have gone much further, and their insults risk undermining my authority.
I can't take much away from a girl I barely know calling me "boring." New pilots do that, too. It starts to sound familiar.
Part of being an officer is learning to weather the insults of young girls who are trying to get a rise out of me.
I'm not sure how you could miss them, frankly. Unless you somehow acquired a propaganda source from Tarak's founders.
It's possible Tarak's founding men left behind historical accounts that remove all traces of women. I don't know how else we could be omitted from colonial records.
It's not my intention to raid this place. I'm here to learn about my ancestral planet and its inhabitants.
I'm not here as a pirate, nor would I act as one alone. I'm seeking information on Earth and its man-woman customs.
I'm here as a tourist. I don't mean you any harm--and on that subject, I would recommend you carry a weapon for self-defense, not an attack dog.
If I were here to attack you, I'd be in my Dread as part of our fleet, not playing cards alone. This is a cultural visit.
I don't have many other clothes in the first place, Myriam. Nor did I suspect this system could be so easily gamed by wearing more.
...You may find it hard to believe, Myriam, but this flightsuit is the most elaborate clothing I have. I also expected more emphasis on poker skill.
...Are you saying I look out of shape, Myriam? I do my best to maintain my figure.
...I keep a strict exercise regimen precisely because I have to fit comfortably in my suit, Myriam. Are you saying I look squeezed into it?
Mejare's culture is built upon the celebration of excess. We do have far more resources than the men's planet, Tarak--but that means the elites see fit to waste them.
Mejarians waste resources on a massive scale just to one-up each other. The planet is beautiful as a result, but not everyone gets to enjoy it.
My homeworld values outer beauty above all. A few civilian districts are nothing if it means the imperial class can continue to gild their gardens.
I'm afraid Earth is our enemy, as well. They consider themselves to be the true human race and see extraplanetary colonists as expendable.
Earth might provide a suitable living space if they weren't also seeking our execution. In their case, it's for our being colonists rather than women.
That's not possible. Earth is Mejare's enemy, too--in fact, it's the enemy of every colony, Tarak included.
Earth is just as hostile to us as Tarak is, if not moreso. Its aim to subjugate every colony--they were the reason we were forced to cooperate with our male prisoners.
We haven't encountered any other female colonies ourselves. Perhaps it was settled before egg-splicing was perfected, so men were kept around to reproduce.
Maybe Mejare isn't the only human settlement dominated by women. If Gamindustri has a small proportion of men, it may be a primitive version of Mejare before women could reproduce on their own.
I don't know enough about other planets to say that. But life on Mejare can be ruthlessly competitive, and those at the bottom of the social ladder have to band together. That includes me.
It takes a stronger connection than body parts to form friendships, man or woman. Our crew is tight-knit, but that's because we're all outlaws.
...No, I don't think so. Not all of the planet is habitable, but pre-colonization scans would have picked up on large, aggressive life forms.
Unless there's monsters on the less industrialized continents, then I don't think so. Even then, we would have detected their presence by now via satellite.
...I don't know for sure, but this doesn't appear to be the Earth of my time. The Earth our crew knows is ecologically devastated.
Earth is Mejare's ancestral homeworld, but this appears to be a version of it that predates the frontier era. For one thing, its atmosphere is intact.
Earth is nearly uninhabitable in my time, and its moon has spun out of orbit. From what I can tell, this is a time before it developed space travel--and its hostility.
I serve the Magno Family pirate outfit of planet Mejare. Though we've recently become closer to vigilantes, as a hostile attack force from Earth has been targeting our homeworld.
Our enemy as of late has been Earth, as its Harvester fleets are attacking our homeworld of Mejare. But we're pirates, so Mejare itself had been our enemy up to this point.
I suspect that this isn't the Earth of my time--for instance, its moon is still in orbit. That may be why you aren't familiar with its colonies.
That might be another reason you don't know of Mejare. There are several factors that lead me to believe that this is a pre-colonial Earth--such as its moon.
That sounds similar to the Omas and Famas of Mejarian couples. Women who are more outgoing and driven tend to become Omas, while Famas are demure and carry children.
...So, women were once meant to care for children, while men did riskier work. That's not unlike the Fama and Oma women of Mejarian couples, respectively.
...Maybe I took too much offense to that. You'd have to ask a doctor--I never received higher education.
It sounds like the kind of thing one would learn in advanced genetics classes. I dropped out of school as a teenager, when I was relocated.
I didn't finish enough school to learn biology at that level. A doctor from Mejare might be able to tell you more.
When we were at our hideout near Mejare, I used to have more breaks. But I'm the only chief pilot on our ship at the moment, so no one else can fulfill my duties completely.
No, I don't. Our ship is stranded away from our hideout on Mejare, and I'm the only pilot of my rank present. So any breaks I used to get are gone.

condition.saying: Just a little quid pro quo

case.state: It's dangerous to believe otherwise. People who are convinced they're perfect are capable of horrifying things.
Not everyone find flaws in themselves. All it takes is an idea of perfection for someone to be convinced that nothing else has a right to exist.
It wasn't totally by choice...there's a large magnetic storm cutting Mejare off from its neighbors. But our nearest neighbor is Tarak, which is inhabited--by men.
Other colonies refer to Mejare as "beyond the Great Magnetic Storm," which has probably done the most to isolate it. We do have one neighbor--Tarak, the male planet.
It's not completely isolated--Mejare has a sister planet called Tarak, where men live. But a magnetic storm makes traveling beyond that dangerous.
We were horrified to discover it, as well. Every planet deals with them differently--some worship them as gods of sacrifice, while others try to survive in a posioned environment.
...It's sickening. As the Dread team leader, I don't go down on the ground much, but I've heard-- ecological destruction, ritualistic sacrifice, resistances crushed.
Its founders split off from the male colonists on their ship, and we artificially splice egg cells to have children. I asked you a question in return.
Women's DNA can be combined via machine, and male colonists settled on Mejare's sister planet Tarak when they were founded. Answer my question before you ask more.
...That won't be necessary. From what I could see from orbit, Earth has many natural beaches.
...You don't need to do that. I saw a lot of coastline between the clouds when I approached Earth.
...So, you would prefer women's company. I'm not used to hearing men say that.
...So, most men there would rather have women present. Is that correct?
We've found that, as well. Male or female, our enemy treats us the same. It's hard to ignore each other's humanity in a situation like that.
...That's right. It was because of our common enemy that we didn't just throw them out the airlock. But because of that, we've found how human we both are.
They each have strengths, which is why we kept them around. The ship only responds to our helmsman, and another is our only doctor. One joined my team as a mech pilot.
Yes--navigation, medical expertise, and mech piloting. We were already shorthanded--the men were all we had to fill those roles.
Other colonists we've met also think it's unusual to not have men around. They might attribute Mejare's social problems to that.
Mejare has its social issues--the existence of pirates is evidence of that. Most colonists seem to think men are necessary for a society to function.

condition.saying: big, ugly men with machine guns

case.state: That sounds like a fitting description for Tarakkians. But I doubt they have any contact with Earth, either.
"Big, ugly men with machine guns" describes Tarakkian soliders very well. Still, they're unlikely to be who you mean.

condition.saying: stealing from them aren't mutually exclusive

case.state: That's true, but our crew has enough enemies as it is. Attacking random civilians won't help us.
You're right to be suspicious, but we don't attack civilians. We're also not seeking any more enemies at the moment.
It seems like there's few places where men and women aren't together on Earth. So much so that schools for girls have a strange reputation.
...So, girls and boys usually go to school together. You seem to coexist almost everywhere.
I only command our Dread team. Who or what we attack is not my decision.
I'm a junior officer--you would have to propose that to our captain. She usually avoids hiring us out.
...Is that how Earthlings see themselves, even in this era? Gods?
...Earthlings from my time have come to see themselves as gods. That tradition must run deep.
...Thank you. I suppose you expected drinking and gambling, but many of us are formerly upper-class.
Most of us come from wealthy backgrounds. They're trying to recreate their old home lives.
...I'm not sure. I wouldn't want either of us to depend on the other.
...I haven't given that much thought. I can take care of myself...I'd want to be with someone who can do that, too.
It was a biological experiment. The Earth of my time plans to harvest our reproductive organs.
It was part of a conspiracy with Earth to create a planet where the uterus could be harvested from the population.
...Even with your supernatural powers, I doubt you can even survive in a vacuum. This Earth must be primitive if that's your idea of space travel.
Do you have no concept of space travel in this time period? You would need a ship, even if you have the power to fly.
I see. I'll try not to pry as to what she's your partner in, exactly.
And what is it you two do together? Actually, maybe it's best that I don't pry.
So this...woman is like me, apparently? Good to know Earth women have all sorts of temperaments.
If that's the case, it'd be nice if she were here. I'd rather be playing with all women.
Couldn't she have come here instead of you, then? I prefer women's company.
It's not a monocle...there's no lens.
I don't blame you for thinking this has a function...but it doesn't.
I can see just fine...this isn't a vision aid.
...I'm sorry. This isn't a monocle...and I shouldn't make a fuss.
"Witch" is the term officials use for man-sympathizers. I don't recommend you go there.
Our crew was once captured and hauled before an imperial court. We got called "witches" for having male colleagues.
So only women can be witches? Mejare's imperials use it to refer to anyone who doesn't despise men.
I think Earth and Mejare may have very different definitions of "witch." Harboring male crewmates earned us the label.
...I see. So Earth isn't a united planet...no wonder I've heard about all the conflict here. Not that Mejare is much better...
Hmm. For Mejare's many problems, every woman there is at least united under one society. I didn't realize Earth had factions...
Britain is just a small part of Earth? Mejare is one society across the whole planet. I can't imagine keeping track of different countries...
Just a country on Earth...how big is it? Planet Mejare is all under one rule, and that's enough trouble without other factions around.
It's...nothing. I'm fine.
I'm sorry, I shouldn't be so worked up about this...
I'm sure there are eyepieces similar to this on Earth. This one was made by my Oma's company...
I don't know Earth very well, so there may well be similar eyepieces. My Oma's company made this one, however...
Mejare is very much terraformed, Daria. My Oma's company made this, but I'm sure you could do so on Earth...
You're quick to make assumptions. I never claimed this was unique to Mejare...though my Oma's company did design it.
...I don't drink.
I'm just making a fuss...don't worry about me. My Oma gave it to me.
It was a gift from my Oma. But I shouldn't be so attached to it...
It's a memento...from my Oma. She died. But don't concern yourself with that...
Eva pilot? What are you on about? Who's this woman I look like?
...Listen, I think you've got me confused with another woman.
Blue hair is common among Mejarians. I think you've got me confused with someone else.
If only I knew whether to appreciate this comparison. I'm not "Ayanami Rei."
I'm a pilot under Magno Vivan. We're pirates.
I pilot for a Mejarian pirate crew.
I'm a pirate. And I don't know what that means.
...Not exactly. I'm not a hero...just trying to survive.
We're not exactly political activists. Just trying to get food and fuel in raids.
That's...far too generous. I'm not a freedom fighter...we just raid the military.
Don't give me that kind of credit...I fight to survive, not for people's freedom.
That would be the polite move, yes.
That's polite, though I don't know why anyone would.
...I hoped as much, Jin.
I expected leaving it on to attract taunts, actually...
Sex toys? That's just crass...if you're looking for the ones shaped like men's tubes, Mejare banned them.
You do seem the type to be curious about that. Mejare has a black market for dildos, since they resemble men...
Earth women like the ones shaped like men's things, correct? When I lived on the streets, I saw smugglers bringing them in...
What are the toys called that look like penises? Dildos? Mejare made those illegal...since it made women attached to men.
...Clearly they don't listen when women speak.
Are you even listening to me? ...Stupid thing to ask of a man.
Well, both you and the man in my squadron confirm men don't bother listening to us.
I hope it's informative, since you don't seem likely to listen to me.
No, it doesn't. It's just for decoration...as far as I know.
It was a gift from my Oma. I can understand why you'd think it'd have a function, though.
It was a gift, and it's just a fashion piece...at least, that's all it is now.
No. If anything, it gets in the way. But it helps me remember my Oma.
I do. How'd you know that? Intuition?
How do you know that? Just from reading my face?
That's right...you're intuitive. Maybe I didn't give you enough credit.
Did someone tell you about that? It's true...my Oma gave this to me.
I don't find it hard to move in my suit at all, actually...or maybe straining against it improves my fitness. I'll take either.
Bodysuits are constrictive at first, but they soon become just another part of you...
I can understand why, but I'd rather not let anything get caught or grabbed while in combat...I've gotten used to the tightness.
Tightness is both constrictive and comforting. And it encourages me to stay in shape...
I find suits much more practical once you get used to them...my crewmate Jura falls more in line with your philosophy.
...I would not trust the dealer with this, Penny, nor anyone else. Neither should you.
...Any establishment that would run strip poker is not one I'd trust my few belongings with, Penny.
I'm afraid I'm not as trusting as you are, Penny. There's only a few women I'd give my eyepiece to...
I've barely met the dealer, Penny, and so have you. Don't be so naive about a seedy place like this.
It was a gift from my Oma.
My Oma gave it to me...before she died.
It was a gift. It doesn't actually do anything.
It's...a memento. My Oma gave it to me before she died.
...I don't know who this "Oboro" is, but this eyepiece was a gift from my Oma.
My Oma gave this to me...shortly before her death. It doesn't do anything.
No, it doesn't help me see. It doesn't do anything...my Oma gave it to me.
...I see there's many being assumptions being made here. I don't play a pirate on TV, Sakura.
...Ah. I'm an actual pirate, not an actor. I understand it's not a common job description.
Ah. We both misunderstood. I'm a pirate in real life, not on television--and I wouldn't appreciate the media attention.
Oh. You think I'm an actress...the media doesn't hound me like that anymore. I pirate for real.
I don't wear this for comfort...or for function.
If you want an equipment discussion, try our quartermaster.
We're pirates. We use what we have.
Pirates can't get picky...although this is a personal item.
Not unless Exspheres is the Earth name for the Nirvana's energy core.
...Well, our ship is powered by a large sphere we call the Paksis Pragma. Does Earth call it an Exsphere?
Not that I know of, Sheena...but the Nirvana's energy source is a large glowing sphere. Is that what you call an Exsphere?
Perhaps you should explain what an Expshere is, Sheena. I can tell you our Paksis Pragma energy core is spherical...
"Anime" and "scouter" are both terms I don't understand.
Earth might have a word for this, but you'd best explain what an "anime scouter" is.
We have scouting equipment, and this isn't part of it. What exactly is an "anime scouter"?
...And what makes scouting equipment "anime," exactly? You can't just throw out Earth words and expect me to understand.
...This is a decorative eyepiece developed by my Oma's company. It was never put to market.
...This is a fashion piece, Twilight. An obscure one. My Oma gave it to me before she died.
...This eyepiece was a gift from my late Oma, Twilight. It's not typical of Mejare's fashion...
...It's a decorative piece, not a monocle. My Oma developed it...but it never reached shelves.
Is that someone I should know?
And who's Ingenium? I assume she's quiet?
I don't have much context for who that is, but alright, then.
I'll have to trust you on the accuracy of that comparison.
That's an overstatement. Because women have to combine eggs on Mejare, we try to control for interesting traits.

There's always a period where a Mejarian couple has to fuse their eggs. It's a chance for them to control for traits they want.
We're just controlled for certain traits while the eggs are fused. My Oma wanted me to have blue hair, like my Fama did...
It's mostly for shocks while flying and the occasional laser on the ground.
It doesn't help all that much...most of my pilots don't wear it. It shows my rank as squadron leader.
It's mostly worn to show my rank. Valore, another squadron leader, wears it as well.
Funny you say that...my Dread is the fastest in the fleet. So I, too, value evasion...
I agree with evasion being superior...better not to take hits at all than try to withstand them.

Like with clothes themselves, Mejare only wears the bare minimum of armor. Weapons are too powerful for it to stop.
...Is Earth armor often for protection, Aella? In a space dogfight, its use is limited...it mainly signifies rank.
My culture? Aside from the odd shock or laser shot, Mejarian armor doesn't do much...we'd rather flaunt ourselves.
Cultures...I assume Earth engages in a lot more ground combat. For a pilot, armor is mostly for peace of mind.
Like home? Aren't you an Earth man?
It's just armor. This isn't combat.
...I recently turned 20. And I'm a pilot, not an engineer...I can't answer scientific questions.
20. As for your theories, they only taught me what I need to know to lead our squadron...not how the ships fly.
I'm afraid I'm only 20, so your theory must be wrong. I don't understand what it is regardless.
Whatever the "theory of relativity" states, I'm only 20...and I'm a pilot. Our engineer, Parfet, might be able to answer your physics questions.
20. Sorry to disappoint, but I only understand the physics of my Dread fighter...not of the "theory of relativity."
I was about to ask why you're being so friendly to a stranger.
I'm not quite sure your image of a pirate aligns with mine...but yes, I am.
That's true. I try not to bring it up unless asked.
Yes, I'm a pirate. It's not glamorous, but the alternative...is living on Mejare. That's far worse.
Piracy is nothing to brag about, but yes, I am one. Fire away.
Yes. I command the Nirvana's Dread squadron. This armor signifies such.
Yes. It's...a stimulating job. But dangerous, hence the armor. All pilots answer to me.
I command the Nirvana's Dread pilots, Futaba. That's why I have this armor--to signify that.
Yes. Not just that, but I am Dread team leader on our ship. Dread commanders wear armor like this.
...I'm listening.
Whatever you're thinking, you're wrong.
I've what?
...You have to be conscientious. I tell new pilots to recognize they won't be spoiled.
Well, you see women die. You can't take anything for granted...that's what we teach new recruits.
That's what's hard to teach new pilots sometimes. Food and beauty is not guaranteed, and your crewmates could die.
...Mejare's populace can be vain. When new women join, I have to teach them they won't be pampered.
Perhaps you can begin by explaining what a Trion is.
You seem excited to tell me about whatever "Trion" is, so you should start.
It's simple padding, with shoulders that deflect lasers. I'm sure "Trion," with all Earth has harvested, is more advanced.
It's by and large a symbol of rank. I stand to learn much more from whatever "Trion" is.
My armor is low on the scale of Mejarian technology. The Paksis might be more comparable to your "Trion."
You're correct. Mejarian dress tends to be revealing...perhaps because we're all women.
This sort of skimpy clothing is actually quite common on Mejare, you're right. The colonists must have felt more comfortable with no men around.
I've noticed Earth women tend to dress more conservatively. It must be because there's men like you around...staring at them.
Do men usually criticize women for being immodest? Because you're correct--Mejare has no men, and we dress much lighter.
No, you can't ride in my Dread, Kamina. Especially not with me.
If this is some sort of proposition for a date, I barely seek out women.
Women have already asked to take a ride in my Dread with me, Kamina. A man has no chance.
This can't be good, after you called me cute...
...There's a lot to address there. Let's start with what a Buddhist is.
...I've fought Mejarian women, Tarakkian men, and Earth machines. I don't know what Buddhists are.
...Are "Buddhists" some sort of threat in Gensokyo? Perhaps it's the Japanese name for the Harvest...
...I'm not a sailor, and the crew has never encountered ghosts. "Buddhist" is the term I'm most curious about there.
I don't need my armor to fly...plenty of my pilots wear no protection at all. It's just a display of rank.
Well, it aids in shocks as I fly...but I don't need it. It's actually to show I'm the squadron leader.
It mostly exists to signify my rank as leader. Still, it's probably saved my life on a few occasions...
It's just armor...it's optional for our pilots. But it shows my rank, so I wear it.
Some women have told me to ditch my armor entirely, actually. It only helps if a shock throws me to the side.
My armor's hardly worth protecting, Penny. I wear it to show authority.
...You don't have much combat experience, do you? Armor doesn't exist to be protected... not that I would bother.

I'm human. Not sure what you are.

I don't know what a Nohrian is, but I'll take your word for it.

...Hm. Well, you try new experiences at your own peril. Strip poker, and now idols.
...Well, I never promised I'd like it. Luckily, I don't plan to live on Earth.

...I'd question how any other woman could make that mistake, Twilight, but not you.
...Suits are generally form-fitting, Twilight. But your grasp of both clothing and anatomy seems tenuous at best.
...I'm not from Earth, Ochako. You shouldn't assume I know what these things mean.
...What's a Quirk? Some Earth way of introducing yourself?

...Whatever a "Quirk" is, I assure you my eyepiece has nothing to do with it.

That does sound like something I had half a mind to say. You're sharp...for a man.

I see all that data of yours is picking up on my speech patterns.
Not a bad imitation of what I'd say. I'd like to meet this woman...

My--boyfriend? Gascogne is the woman who runs our weapons systems, and I have nothing but respect for her.

Wha--as if I'd have a boyfriend. Gascogne is the woman who serves as the Nirvana's quartermaster, and I show her respect.
...Gascogne is a woman's name, and the brave woman who runs our weapons systems. Don't set me up with men.

What? Of course I do...that'd be indecent. I don't want to be here, you know.

As far as I'm concerned, Penny, bodysuits are the perfect outfit. Simple, unrestrictive, and shows off your body.

That just sounds like decoration for vanity's sake. I used to be from a wealthy family...and your model has been retired, speaking of the past.
...I appreciate your eye for style, Rarity, but that's not the kind of thing I value in a suit. I need function...would your new version agree?

I can breathe just fine, Sola, so don't worry about me. Wearing this has become second nature.

Either I pilot in this or in the one sundress I own. The tightness feels good...both secure and unrestrained.

Energy propulsion. You'd have to ask Parfet for the details.

AT Field? I told you, I don't know what you're talking about.

Ugh...I didn't think a man would be so transparent in leering at me. But you did already call me cute...

A man calling me cute and then leering at my chest...Tarakkians would be shrieking in terror, seeing a woman strip.
I can't believe I'm stripping for a man...especially one who called me cute, and isn't terrified of women.

A dogfight is much more stressful than showing my breasts off, Penny. Better not to dwell on it...

If a pilot can't face down a few strangers bare-chested, she'd never be able to face down the enemy.
Piloting is about split-second decisions, not second-guessing yourself. Bare breasts are low on my list of worries.
That's in your best interest, Pit.
Among Mejarians, at least, my chest leaves something to be desired...
You had expectations? Where men stand on breasts is a mystery to me.
I'm surprised a winged man even has expectations here...let's see how I do.
Yes, Mejare is populated only by women. Men only entered my life about a year ago...aside from raids on Tarak.
That's correct. I didn't see a man in person until a few years ago...a dead one.
Mejare is all women, yes. I didn't exchange words with a man until I was nineteen.
Yes. Mejare is known as the planet of women...it wasn't until I became a pirate that I saw a man in the flesh.
That's right. I still remember the first man I ever saw in person...a dead Tarakkian soldier during a raid.
Well, if you're a hero, confidence would probably inspire the people you interact with.
I try to maintain confidence. If the leader loses faith, so will everyone else.
It's just my breasts...if I didn't have the confidence for this, I'd have no place among the crew.
Confidence is a good trait in a woman, no matter your station in life...so I'd agree.

Well, you can't let the enemy see you sweat...and the crew shouldn't see it, either.
It's part of my job. I would think a goddess would understand the need for a leader to stay calm.
If I panic, the whole squadron will. A leader has to be stoic...you, as a goddess, must understand that.
Is that what Earth people call male and female parents? I had parents...they were both women, that's all.
I was technically made in a lab...but it was from my parents' eggs.
I had parents, just not a male one...my Fama carried me like your Earth mothers.
I had parents...I'm not a robot, despite what my crewmates might have to say on the matter.
Actually, by Mejare's standards, I can be skittish with nudity. I understand Earth is more conservative.
I have plenty of crewmates with better figures who show off more skin. But on Earth, even my suit is scandalous, right?
Among Mejarians, I might differ, Akko--I have a pilot who only wears a leotard and boots. Maybe on this planet...
Actually, I've been teased before over wanting to be more private with my body. But Mejarian modest seems to be Earth risqu.
I think our planets may differ on shame, Akko--plenty of my pilots walk around with their cleavage and backsides visible. I try to be presentable.

Why would I protest? I lost fair and square.
Protest? Mejarians are taught to be proud of their bodies. Decent advice as far as Mejare goes.
Frivolous what?
Pirates aim for ruthless efficiency, actually.
Pirates bother with whatever they have to. And deep down, we're still women.
Hm? Right, you wanted to see mine. Well, it's not as if I've earned the right to modesty...
I don't want to show you my backside, but if you're going to keep insisting...

What? Fine...since you seem so interested, for whatever reason.
I should've known...you're still trying to win me over. This really is a new experience, having a man flirt with me...
Oh, of course...it's because you think I'm cute. This is certainly more praise than I expected...
Oh, I'd hate to give up against a man. I'm sorry I'm not the type to return your flirting...
...Do you really think I'm attractive? What men want eludes me...but thank you.
Jura is my second-in-command. She's...she does a good job, but she's too vain. It'd be nice to have her here, though.
...Yes, I suppose I'd be more comfortable with her here. She's my crewmate--and she bolted for another table.
Jura is one of my pilots. We came here together, but she ran off...I would've preferred we stuck together on a foreign planet.
...Jura is my backup command. She's the picture of Mejarian beauty...and yes, I'd like her here, even if she's vain.
I can handle myself alone, Penny. But Jura and I lead the squadron...so I'm used to her being around.
Actually, Pit, I'm just getting started.
If you think being naked is going to rattle me, Pit, I've been through much worse.
Almost over? I'm finishing this game on my terms.
I wouldn't underestimate a cornered woman, Pit. Neither should you.
Hair? Hate to break it to you...
I'm afraid they're going to have to keep waiting, Sei.
Hair? Hair belongs on the head...nowhere else.
Hair belongs on the head alone...though men don't seem to believe in that.
Thank you for the compliments, Sola, but I'm plain by Mejare's standards...
Actually, I'd say most Mejarian women are better-looking. It's the populace's claim to fame.
If there's one thing Mejarians are obsessed with, it's beauty. I'm on the lower end of the scale, I assure you.
If I'm piquing your interest, seeing what Mejare calls "beautiful" might put you into shock.
Mejarians breed and engineer for beauty. I fell by the wayside in that department...I just try to stay fit.

There isn't much to say about how Mejarians style...because there isn't much to see.
I may be a pirate, Zizou, but there are still Mejarian trends I follow...like shaving.
Style? Well...I hope you weren't excited to see blue pubic hair.
...Why would I do that? I was hoping you could improve its fit or practicality...
I don't have any diamonds, Rarity. Even a diamond pattern would be needless flash.
That just sounds like decoration for vanity's sake. I used to be from a wealthy family...but I'm a pirate now.
...I appreciate your eye for style, Rarity, but that's not the kind of thing I value in a suit. I need function.
It's embarrassing enough to have to show my breasts, but to be the first to do so...
I wonder if Jura thinks she can get more clout on the Dread team like this, knocking me down a peg via public humiliation.
...I'm flushed, aren't I? If the blood rushes to my breasts instead of my face, it might make them look bigger...
No one else has even exposed themselves...I feel like I've been captured by Earth's forces and studied as an alien woman.
This game can really make someone feel alone in a group.
I think this may be an Earth conspiracy. I help destroy its Harvest fleet, it humiliates me in public...
My goal tonight was to gather information on Earth. Instead, I'm the one being studied...
...This is the least important...as you can see.
...My eyepiece...
...Nobody take this...I'll find a place for it.
...There's no sense...in leaving this on.
...This must not seem like much...
...Where's the safest place to put this? I don't want it getting lost...
...I'll take this off...but I'm still holding onto it.
...You probably thought this eyepiece was strange-looking...
...You might think this eyepiece is Mejarian fashion, but my crewmates are just as unfamiliar...
At least I can get out of this armor now. I only wear it around in case we have to scramble.
This armor is a pain anyway. Its best use is signifying my authority.
Give me a moment. This armor is pressurized...and clunky.
Sleep, showering, and exercise...those are the only times my armor comes off.
I've read body armor on Earth can be rather elaborate...in a dogfight, it can feel irrelevant.
Maybe this will calm my nerves...my suit is tight enough, and my armor is pressurized.
...This is just standard pressurized armor. You can see the outline of my shoulders now, at least.
Perhaps you're curious why I'd wear armor here...I don't trust Earth, but it's just out of habit.
