Mejare is a terraformed planet...it's not in our culture to cover ourselves. Why does a "monster" reveal so much?
Mejare is climate-controlled, so bodysuits are the fashion. I suppose monsters have your own reasons for dressing scant...
Mejare prides itself on being the temperate paradise of female beauty...do monsters try to attract each other the same way?
The women of Mejare form couples...so we put our breasts and hips on display in clothing like this. Why would a "monster"?
Big? You're referring to...my breasts? Wearing armor for that purpose would just be sad.
...Is that why you wear your armor? Insecurity over your chest or not, that's just dishonest.
What? I wear that armor to show rank and protect myself, not--to make my breasts look big.
Are you saying that my breasts look big? No one's ever described them that way...and I certainly wouldn't wear armor just to fool people.
Perhaps if I were a more cowardly woman, I'd try to argue that the suit counts as two pieces. But three?
The suit is clearly one layer, Catria. It's my own fault for not dressing for the game properly--I won't be making excuses.
If you'd like to describe to me how a bodysuit counts as two pieces, let alone three, then please enlighten me.
Strong women accept the consequences of their choices, Catria. Cowards try to count one item as three.
Perhaps I look better from this angle. You be the judge...I wasn't looking to compare, Connie.
...How does my backside look? I can actually improve it through exericise, unlike my breasts...that's not necessary, Connie.
What? Oh...your duel. ...Men gain muscle at an impressive rate. If I could trust one not to attack, then I'd let him lift me up...
...I should've known you'd ask something like that. It's not their rods--maybe their muscle growth. I wouldn't mind one lifting me up...gently.
Right...your duel. I do like men's muscles. Not only is it utilitarian, but their strength would help in...breast massages.
...I expected a question about men. I know they can grow muscle very well compared to us...I wish I trusted one enough to let him massage me.
...I knew I'd be answering this...I had so little clothing. Men are bulky compared to women, and I'd like to...explore their muscles.

state.text: For a woman who claims not to "have her shit together," you're very confident you could capture me.
Earth has no reward money for me, I assure you. Mejare certainly does... but let's see you claim it.
It's just like a soldier to hang a threat above her victim's head. For your own sake, stay over there.
And I'd be enjoying the game with both of you gone. I promise you, the reward money isn't worth the conflict.
...Yes, I'd prefer the body questions, too. As you can tell, I'm not terribly shy about it.
I think your viewers would prefer questions about my body, too. As would I--since I'm constantly displaying it.
...I'm more comfortable talking about my figure, too. Surely your audience would prefer a hips-and-breasts discussion.
Body questions would be better, yes. I'd like some feedback on my stomach and waist...or my backside.
...Exotic and erotic. Is it the way I dress, or the allure of a woman unspoiled by men?
Why exactly am I so fascinating? Or...erotic? My skintight suit? My unfamiliarity with men?
Earthlings seem to find something appealing in a woman who's never been with a man...or shows her body off.
...I certainly thought Earthlings would find me exotic, but erotic? Because of my suit, or...because of men?
Busy interviewing someone else, I hope. Hmm...how do men show they're in love with a woman?
Does that mean she'll ignore me now? Well...er...if a man is in love with a woman, how would she know that?
...Well, Sei...men fall in love with women, don't they? Do they express that the same way we do?
I don't know how much experience you have, Sei, but...what are the signs a man is in love?
Sei...well, I have a different sort of question. When a man falls in love with you, how does he act? ...How should I?

case.state: Go missing? Evas are some kind of exploration craft, then?
So she was a space explorer, then...piloting an "Eva." I'm sorry to hear that.
Perhaps if I had a picture of this woman...I can assure you, I'm not the reason she's missing.
Missing...there's few enough of us that I can monitor the status of all my pilots. A shame to hear that...
So she went missing...I'm sorry to hear that. Is there an "Eva" mech I can study somewhere?
Missing...hmm. If Earth has "freaky Eva mechs," it might use them against us...I'd like to see one.
...So you suspect that the Eva vessel she piloted had something to do with her disappearance? They sound fearsome...where are they?
...I see. She went missing. I considered our Vandread technology fearsome, but perhaps these "Evas" are a different beast.

state.text: I barely even know how men's tubes work, and you make these obscene requests...Sei, I can't have a relationship.
Where do you get the nerve to ask me these things? As far as I know, men are still a hostile species...as are soldiers.
Not everyone is an exhibitionist, Streaming-chan. And I worry men might sprout tendrils...that's not an invitation, Sei.
Maybe you like to degrade yourself for viewers, but I do not. ...Sei, there are plenty of women on Mejare I ignore, too.

case.state: ...Shut up. Quiet. ...Sei, don't be stupid. I can't be claustrophobic...that's just weakness.
...Quiet. Quiet! ...I'm not claustrophobic, Sei, I'm...well.
...I said I don't like them. Now shut your mouth! ...Claustrophobic? Don't be ridiculous...
...My Dread is the only tight space I like. Now be quiet! ..."Claustrophobic"? No one's ever called me that...

state.text: ...Streaming-chan? I see...she won't be finding much. It's a long flight to Mejare.
...Hm. How do you propose she actually search for them? Even as faster-than-light, Mejare is months away from here.
Are you even listening to me? ...Apparently not. Well, between the distance and imperial policy, she won't find much.
Hello? ...I see. That'll be a long shopping trip for products that are probably superior on Earth.
...Is nothing sacred to you, Streaming-chan? Are you here to make me appreciate the soldier's company?
...Ghoulish indeed. Did you bring this pathetic friend of yours to make yourself look better, Sei?
...You're disgusting. Sei, you actually call this woman your friend? She certainly makes you look better.
...I'll say this, Sei. Even for a soldier, you have more of a heart than this soulless attention-seeker.

case.state: ...There's no need to waste time and resources to impress ignorant Earth children.
...Just take this as an example of the xenophobia bred into Earth's younger generation. We should focus on their fleets.
...She's not worth the effort, Jura. We should be striking fear into Earth's Harvest fleets, not its schoolchildren.
...Earth children are taught not to value our humanity, Jura. A show of strength won't change that.
...Thank you, Jura. You're a talented pilot, as well...you just need more leadership experience.
...You're a fine pilot, too, Jura. You just need to practice maintaining that skill when you have to lead the team.
...Jura is second-in-command on our team, and a fine pilot in her own right. As well as more adept socially.
...There's no need to praise me so much. You and the other pilots are skilled, as well...I should let you lead the team more.
Sei and I both shaving is coincidence. I can only assume the women of Planet China are covered in hair...including their backsides.
Shaving is the style on Mejare...ask Sei if you want to know about Earth. Planet China must be fully committed to pubic hair...possibly anal hair, as well.
I'm sorry if you were hoping to see blue pubic hair, Mulan, but it exists. Planet China must encourage its woman to grow hair...freely.
Feel free to display the anal hair Planet China values, Mulan. I don't know Sei's situation.
My pubic hair is thick without shaving...and it's indeed blue. Do the women of Planet China not shave...anything?
...Thank you. Most of my crewmates probably wouldn't choose my company, even if they respect me.
...I understand what you mean. Of course, pleasant company isn't everything--that's not what my crewmates respect me for.
A man as the level-headed member of a fighting team? That hasn't been my experience...
I assume you're the cooler head in this arrangement, then? The men I fight alongside tend to be excitable.
Then you must be the more steadfast member. Usually that falls to me...with men being reckless.
The men I know are usually the reckless ones...and short, as well. So this is a new arrangement to see...
I'd like to be the arbiter of that, thank you. I'm my own person.
...I'll take your word for it that it is. Sounds like I'd get along with this woman.
I never saw myself as having much in common with others, but apparently there's an Earth woman I'm very similar to.
I feel like I've been captured on Tarak and displayed in a cage...who is this mystery woman?
Mejare has few animals...mostly in zoos. I now realize they didn't want us to see male ones.
Any animals you see on Mejare are most likely in captivity. They don't want males on display...
Far be it from Mejarian imperials to let us see male animals. Most are hoarded in captivity and hidden away...
I saw some animals in zoos as a girl...all female, of course. Show any male ones, and it might've caused suspicion.
Yes, I lead our ship's Dread fighter squadron. That means I can't compromise the team with personal flings.
Every fighter pilot on the Nirvana answers to me, in fact. Flirting with them would only undermine my authority.
...I have more than a few trainees in our pilot squadron. If I tried to date one of them, the others wouldn't take me seriously.
Yes, I do. But one of a leader's responsibilities is setting a rookie straight when she's busy ogling your backside.
Your male teammate wears a skintight suit, as well? Men don't seem like they're shaped properly for that...
I think your complaints may stem from your gender, Ryuji. Women are smooth and shapely for bodysuits...men are angular and jagged.
I would think men aren't built to wear bodysuits properly. Wouldn't your tube bunch up and get in the way?
If Futaba and I enjoy our suits, and you don't, Ryuji...it's likely because men aren't built for them. You're too inflexible.
By my estimates, men like smashing things and wearing baggy pants to hide their tubes from women's fangs.
The men I know like many things, and women aren't one of them. And their clothes tend to be spacious...
Men dress...in baggy clothing, correct? And they like fighting amongst themselves, but not women.
I think I've gathered those details already. All the men I know wear baggy, loose clothing and like avoiding women to scheme amongst themselves.
I'm totally lost in this conversation...but the idea of a teenager spying on a clandestine government organization is pretty amusing.
I'll be honest...if she is, I side with the teenager over the state. Good for you, Futaba.
That's a funny thought. Listen, Futaba, if you need protection from the law, the Nirvana has room for you.
Rebelling against authority? I like you, Futaba. Keep up the good work.
Guess Earthlings have more intellectual ways of rebelling against the state than shooting lasers...
...Well? Mejare is one of Earth's colonies. My ancestors were Earth women...and men, I suppose.
...Mejare and Tarak are both natural wastelands, but Mejare has been terraformed somewhat. Anything else?
...Such as? We're taught from a young age to hate them. They showed me films of men eating our livers.
...Can you be more specific? We reproduce by splicing eggs together, and our sister planet is Tarak--where the men live.
To be honest, one of the reasons I came here was the chance to become more comfortable with men. It seems that won't be happening.
It's certainly more comfortable having no men here, but I was a little curious about their...tubes.
I won't lie...part of me wanted to see a man naked tonight. Their...things just seem so ridiculous...
With no men here, it's easier for me to admit I was curious about seeing one nude...and if I had the nerve to strip near them.
I avoid relationships even with the other women. Being with a man is just... preposterous.
I--don't be ridiculous. I focus on my work, not leering at my crewmates.
You--you're just making fun of me. I'm not interested in any relationships.
Oh, for God's sake...I didn't come here to gossip about men. I don't even approach my female crewmates.

state.text: ...That might be an exaggeration.
...Speaking of crime, cameras in my face remind me of my mugshots.
...I really don't. But it's clear you're not actually interested.
...I don't have time for this interview when there's work to do.
I told you there wasn't much to say. If you want Mejarian technology, ask about my Dread.
I'd much rather discuss my piloting than anything on my person. If your viewers want that, all the better.
I don't need your viewers' approval. Next time, ask about my ship...or my body.
What did you expect? My Dread ship is a much better example of technology.
...So it is a fetish here. To be reduced to a pornography symbol...
I can't believe my upbringing is the stuff of pornography and fetishes on this planet...
This is not what I expected...Earth treating Mejarians like fetish fuel.
I should've figured they'd find me exotic. Men are the same way for me...
...I should've known I'd be interrogated about Mejare.
...Surely women have formed relationships on Earth? There can't be much to teach about Mejare.
Questions for me? ...I didn't think I'd be a Mejarian tour guide, but perhaps I should have.
Questions for me...? Maybe I shouldn't have said anything. Mejare can't be that different.
Go missing? Evas are some kind of exploration craft, then?
So she was a space explorer, then...piloting an "Eva." I'm sorry to hear that.
Perhaps if I had a picture of this woman...I can assure you, I'm not the reason she's missing.
Missing...there's few enough of us that I can monitor the status of all my pilots. A shame to hear that...
Make decent requests, then. I don't even know how their--tubes work.
Being a pirate does not mean I'm without dignity. Don't suggest that again.
That's a ridiculous thing to ask of a stranger. If I were with anyone, it'd be--somewhere private.
If you want to degrade yourself for popularity, be my guest. Don't involve me in it.
Don't ask me to suddenly have sex with a species I've been taught will kill me. I'm still not sure that's false...
...Quiet. You know nothing of being a space pirate.
...Don't talk about that. Ever.
...No, I don't like them. Stop pestering me.
...My ship is the only tight space I like.
I wasn't lying to preserve my modesty. My outfit seems to be scandalous on Earth, anyway.
Surely my style of dress is titillating enough. I wasn't misleading you...
I have a hard time believing you're capable of personal questions. Toys are simply a curiosity where I'm from...
I'm sure you can find better products on this planet. After all, men are right here for them to be modeled after.
Of course it's horrible. Read a book on the subject if you're so inclined.
Perhaps if you had colleagues, Streaming-chan, you wouldn't treat their deaths as entertainment.
Are you expecting me to describe that in detail? You disgust me.
You're pathetic. You'd advertise descriptions of women's deaths for attention?

case.state: We all have to live the lives we're given. My pilots depend on me for vigilance in the face of threats, not defeatism.
My aim is to keep my subordinates calm in a firefight, not to wallow in depression. If I felt it were hopeless, I wouldn't be on the crew.
I recognize the danger of our situation and seek to maintain my composure. It has nothing to do with feeling sorry for myself.
I don't need your pity--I was only explaining our situation. I take this same tone with my pilots so that they remain focused.
It's certainly Mejare's point of view that we don't need men. Though our prisoners have proven themselves to be valued crew members.
That's Mejare's founding principle. It took some time for us just to accept men's presence aboard our ship. Of course, I owe my life to each of them now.
Any self-respecting Mejarian would agree with you that men are the enemy. I would have, too, until I was forced to work together with them.
You've just described a Mejarian's entire worldview. I was disgusted when we integrated men into our crew. Now, I realize we would never have survived without them.
I'm not sure which word means which. "Straight" as in a man's tube, once his blood rushes to it?
...Does "straight" mean a woman prefers to date men? I know their rod-organs stiffen and become straight.
What does either word mean? "Straight" sounds like it has to do with men's tube-organs, and "gay" just sounds vague.
From what I understand, the Earth of this time hasn't yet developed space travel. But all colonists are descended from spacefaring Earthlings, who seem to only have had two sexes.
That may not make much sense for me to say about the Earth of this time. But every colony like Mejare was once an Earthling settlement--Earth defines what humans are.
All humans on other planets trace their ancestry back to colonists from Earth, so you represent the basis of what humanity is. It seems like you haven't settled those colonies yet in this time.
...What? No. I mean the use of artificial gene-splicing to produce the children of women couples.
...What are you talking about? I'm saying women can't reproduce naturally, so we splice egg cells by artificial means.
...Machines to properly splice the DNA of Oma and Fama mothers, so Mejarian couples can have children.
Pirates have no need for money. Whatever we find on a raid, it goes to our collective treasury.
Money is irrelevant to me now. For doing my duty as a pilot, I'm given a bed and a meal ticket.
Yes. I understand that's unusual for most human settlements. Both Mejare and Tarak were intentionally settled as single-sex worlds.
Yes. Tarak and Mejare are the only colonies we know of with single-sex populations. Humans on other worlds always seem to find that unsettling.
You look like you have combat experience. Considering the threats we've found in just a few nebulas, it makes sense other small bands of fighters would crop up.
...I guess it'd be foolish to assume our crew is the only independent fighting outfit around, or that the Harvest is the only threat. We've only been traveling for less than a year.
It doesn't do anything. It was a gift from my Oma.
It has no function. My Oma gave it to me.
Mejare is a terraformed planet. Its seasons are mild.
...Mejare is climate-controlled for human habitation. Our ship is even more so.
Mejare's climate is made artificially temperate. Snow is a rare occurrence and is often deliberate for Christmas...
Terraforming has made Mejare's seasons mild. And even the gravity on our ship is artificial, let alone its heat.
So it is women's hair. I'll inform Hibiki about that.
Well, Corrin does look rather feminine. But then, there's masculine-looking women I respect.
Well, Corrin does look rather feminine. But I object to the idea that "feminine" means weak.
...My planet of origin, perhaps. But other women from Mejare have told me that, too...
..."Something different." My homeworld would be the biggest culprit...but I've heard that from fellow Mejarians, too.
...I've heard that from women on the streets...my crewmates...and our captain. They all meant different things...
Our quartermaster said something was "different" about me when I joined the crew...I'm still not sure what she meant.
...I am the Dread team leader, not the captain. But it's clear you aren't taking me seriously.
...Is this what Earth children are taught? That there are no extraplanetary civilizations, and to insult the very notion?
...Apparently the very concept of Earth's colonies is considered laughable here. We will repel your forces all the same.
...You think my homeworld a joke. If I valued the opinion of a teenage brat, I would demonstrate my Dread's firepower to you.
I see. And you left that to work with men? Our crew only did so out of necessity...
I command a Dread squadron for a pirate group of all women. Until we were forced to work with men...did that happen to you?
That's not an arrangement I'd leave willingly to work with men...or was it not willing?
...Earth women still prefer to work with each other, then? Unless you were a special case...
What's it pressurized for? Good question...I think Mejarians just like tight clothing.
I can only assume it's pressurized so it feels better when one takes it off, Aella. Tightness is a style...
If something can be tightened, Mejarians will do it. Your armor seems a bit unwieldy.
Why's it pressurized? Even with armor, Mejare seeks form-fitting clothing. It almost becomes a part of me.
Pressure is Mejare's style. It can be uncomfortable, but heavy metal armor doesn't seem much better.
...You're familiar with Mejarian armor?
...What exactly has made you familiar with Mejarian flightsuit armor?
...A man built your ship? It must be bulky...women's designs aim for sleekness.
Contacting a male engineer would create clashing design elements. Tarak's ships have heavy armor and firepower, unlike ours...
A male shipwright? He would probably see elements of both bulky male ships and slender female ones in the Nirvana...
If a man designed your ship, I imagine it's loaded down with heavy artillery. We aren't used to the Nirvana's lack of agility.
Forfeit? What are you talking about?
...Whatever this "forfeit" is, I don't like the sound of it.
I'm limber with the armor on. It'd be useless otherwise. And what's that about a forfeit?
If you think I'll be masturbating tonight, then men are dumber than I thought.
Don't count on it. You don't seem too spectacular at cards for all your talk.
As if I'd lose to a man. Don't count on it.
...We don't target civilians or the police, but yes. Most of our recruitment comes from common citizens. It's flashy...but also dangerous.
...We only commit crimes in the eyes of the military. Targeting civilians would be foolish--we need them to join our ranks.
...I'll let you decide how "awesome" our activity is. We focus on the military because our recruits tend to be disgruntled civilians.
...There's not enough to gain in attacking the police or common citizens, and we'd make too many enemies. The work is...stimulating.
For an even shorter search, I could just ask Barnette for one of hers...
I have a pilot who wears flowers in her hair. I could walk ten feet to her quarters and get a bow.
I would have a very short search for a bow on our ship, where my pilot Barnette has a collection.
I have a crewmate who would probably lend me a bow, Leggy. Not to mention a pistol...
...You started this conversation, and now you don't want to have it.
...Are male parents a touchy issue on Earth? You're the one who brought it up.
...Natsuki, don't ask me questions and then decide to back out.
...The least you could do is not waste my time. I tell my pilots the same thing when they can't spit out a report.
I don't know why you'd think I'd know what a lesbian is.
Women functioning without men must seem extremist to Earthlings. And lesbian, whatever that means.
...I don't know what a lesbian is, but yes, Mejare probably seems extremist towards men.
...What's a lesbian? Mejare's government would certainly call us extremists for being pirates...
Photograph me if you want. Nobody knows who I am.
Take pictures if you want. I doubt they'll reach Mejare.
Are you taking photographs? If this reaches the ship, Jura will never take me seriously again.
I have bad memories of my picture being taken...or good, in a way.
Are you taking photographs? I'd like to see you try to blackmail a pirate.
Take pictures if you want. My Wanted mugshot is outdated anyway.
...You used to. I'll remember your case during my daily squats routine.
The image of your oversized backside is plenty of motivation for more lunges in the future.
I'll keep that in mind when I hit the gym tomorrow, Erufuda.
I'm actually quite proud of the muscle on my butt. And if it means avoiding your pudgy fate, I'll do even more squats.
There's no reason you can't get it back, Erufuda. I consider my butt my best asset, and that's because I worked for it.
...Thank you, Leafy. I do my best to maintain it.
...Thank you, Leafy. A woman can't build up her breasts with exercise like with her butt...so I prefer the latter.
...I've always seen "beautiful" as something inborn, not trained. But...thank you.
...Toning my backside gives me a clear goal for my exercise. Thank you, Leafy.
I'm not armed to the teeth at all, Sei...in fact, I'm more vulnerable than ever, turning my back like this...
"Armed to the teeth?" Here...as a gesture of trust, I'll turn around. That way you can see my backside...
I only came armed with my laser ring, Sei. You're the one who's been boasting about her equipment...so here's mine.
I'm not "armed to the teeth," Sei. I only brought a basic firearm... and whatever my butt has to offer.
...So, men like women with no pubic hair? Or do they love shaving themselves? Or both?
...I'm confused. Do men enjoy shaved women, or do they enjoy shaving their own pubic hair?
...Men have pubic hair, don't they? Are you saying they like shaving that, or that they like shaved women?
If men like shaved women, Mejare would be a paradise...except we'd kill them. Or are you saying men shave themselves?
So, men are fans of sleekness, too, then? Either on themselves...or on the women they chase?
...You mean they like shaved women? Men seem to have hair everywhere else, so I can't see them shaving themselves...
Photograph me if you want. Nobody knows who I am...especially not by my butt.
Take pictures if you want. I doubt they'll reach Mejare...or that anyone will recognize my butt.
Are you taking photographs? If this reaches the ship...well, they know what I look like naked.
I have bad memories of my picture being taken...a photograph of my backside isn't nearly as bad.
Are you taking photographs? I'd like to see you try to blackmail a pirate...and one who's not afraid to show her backside in public.
Take pictures if you want. My Wanted mugshot is usually from the front.
Take pictures if you want, Shego. I'd be impressed if Mejarian imperials could identify me by my rear.
...You seem to equate normal human sexuality with aggressive perversion. Do men just force themselves upon you?
Staring at a woman's nude backside is normal, Zone-tan. Spreading myself open for men and monsters...is less so.
...What does "hornily" mean to you? That it's fair for a man to pounce on me from behind and...insert his tube?
To react "hornily" is to stare at a woman's butt. What you're suggesting is that I bend over and present to any raging tentacle...or tube.
...I'm glad you have a sense of humor, Emi. I could say the same thing about your breasts...
...And so are yours, Emi, from my point of view.
Yours are still growing, Emi. Otherwise, I might make the same comment...
The reverse would be true if you visited Mejare. I knew coming here that my body would be scrutinized, as a foreigner...
Mhmhm...you do have a good attitude about fitness, Emi. Remember my piloting offer.
I was hoping you'd feel the same way, Emi. Squats work wonders...you really would make a good recruit.
Mhmhm...I was just about to make a similar comment about toned backsides. You would fit in well on our team, Emi.
I appreciate how the butt can be improved through training...oh, you agree, Emi? You would be a good influence on some of our trainees...
...Perhaps that's what truly makes me alien, then. What are they?
...What are they? I didn't expect to rattle a man just from that. Perhaps I'm more alien than I thought.
...Maybe I am an alien. Is it really so shocking not to know? Enlighten me, then...
...Normally it takes a gun in his face to shock a man. What are "Pokemon"? Maybe it'll make me more human...
Tch...that's easy to offer when my breasts are exposed. A Mejarian never makes herself vulnerable to a man...
Questions about the male sex? ...I might be in a more quizzical mood if I weren't so vulnerable now...
It's a bit late to make such an offer, N...I'd rather interrogate a man armed. And clothed...
You weren't distracting me...this is the game. But I would've preferred learning about men with my breasts armored...
Darkness is a comrade of yours, isn't she? What's her training routine?
...My routine is mild at best, Megumin. Perhaps I could learn some fitness tips from your teammate...how does she train each day?
I don't doubt that your teammate could be stronger than me...I could always train harder. What's her daily regimen?
...You shouldn't praise something as simple as toned abs, Megumin. Have you observed Darkness's training routine?
What makes you say that? We have dedicated suits for spacewalks...the suit is just Mejarian fashion.
I assume you mean my outfit. We wear baggy spacesuits for raids...but this is just fashion.
An astronaut? This is for piloting...the suits we wear for space are much clunkier.
I'm not sure how. Our spacesuits are one-size-fits-all...this bodysuit is just a common Mejarian outfit.
"A bit" of muscle? Clearly I need to do more squats...is that what you're really after?
You're one to talk about muscle, Kazuma. You're scrawny for a man...is this a ploy to watch me exercise?
One would think a man would understand that muscle can be soft or firm. One squat would reveal that--you can fantasize if you want.
...Knowing you, Kazuma, I'm sure you'd like to observe my squat routine as I develop that "bit of muscle."
I...have already met "males." But since they're crewmates, I can't exactly ask to see their anatomy...
...There are a few men on our ship. That's enough for me--but here, I can learn about men's physiology.
For purely scientific purposes, yes. An Earth stripping game lets me observe both men's anatomy and their culture.
I've already met several men--the prisoners on our ship. This game is for observation purposes...since I can't just inspect them.
...Tamaraneans are rather...promiscuous, aren't they? Or is that your breeding practice?
...At the same time? We form couples on Mejare, not...orgies.
...I can't tell if this excitement over men passing you around is an Earth influence, or just Tamaranean culture.
...If I were to ever be with a man, it'd be one man. Do Tamaraneans breed with several at a time?
Maybe that's true, but Earth is not my standard of comparison...
You can always compare yourself to someone worse. But I come from the planet of feminine beauty.
That's small comfort when my homeworld is famous for its beautiful women...
The expectations are different on Mejare for this sort of thing...but thank you.
...It's something you could develop yourself, Starfire. With your height, it'd look even better.
...Thank you, Starfire. You have a fine figure yourself, and toning the butt is fairly easy.
...You have longer legs, Starfire. You could show off a toned backside better than I could with the same squat routine.
...Well, I do enjoy how my backside can actually be improved with exercise. So could yours, to greater effect...
...You'll be happy to know that Mejarians dress light. Me especially so, to aid in combat.
I regard accessories as combat hinderances, so yes, that will be all.
Any extra baubles dangling off my body would only interfere with my work. You won't see any more.
You'll get what you want, then. I dress to fight and to fly, not to impress.
...If you were to wear this armor, you'd have to lead a Dread team. Are you asking for a job?
...I don't mean to offend, Jessie, but you don't seem the type to engage in combat, or lead a Dread squadron. Would you?
This armor is actually a rank signifier as a Dread team leader, so if you'd like to manage a team of young pirates learning to fly, we can find a place for you.
It pressurizes, so I'm sure it could be adjusted properly. More to the point, though--would you be up to leading a team of Dread pilots?
Typically, squadron leaders wear this armor. We could actually use more women of your age on board...but could you handle that?
...Tomoko, are you staring at me again? Even with my back turned, I can feel it...
...Tomoko, I told you I don't appreciate being stared at. Though this time, I've certainly given you something to stare at...
Now to place my shorts somewhere...Tomoko, are you staring at my butt? You've been sneaking glances at me...
I suppose you've all earned the right to see my backside, as well...if you're still staring, Tomoko, you're not unlike my younger pilots.
I hope my backside is enough of a reward for stripping me down like this...it's nothing my suit doesn't show, Tomoko.
Here I am from the back, if you were curious...I'm used to women seeing my butt, Tomoko. My suit lifts it up.
My suit always accentuates my backside--here it is, in the flesh. ...I get comments on my butt a lot, Tomoko. It's no issue.
I suppose I owe you all a glance at my back. ...It's nothing, Tomoko. The whole crew knows what my butt looks like, anyway.
Here I am, from every angle...it's funny you say that, Tomoko. My suit shows my backside all the time, and some women are drawn to my stoicism...
...Thank you, Panty. I make a point of doing regular squats and stretches...that's not an invitation to stretch it.
The butt is an important muscle, and probably the one I target most in my exercise. ...You don't plan to touch it, do you, Panty?
My backside is the result of daily squats. I appreciate the compliment, Panty...unless you plan on spanking me.
Perhaps it's to make up for my modest breasts, but I train my butt quite a bit. ...Knowing you, Panty, you won't stop at compliments.
...I didn't have this butt to see for much of my life, Panty. It's from exercise...I'm sure you'd like to watch me squat.
...One part of Mejarian culture is that girls are taught to listen to others.
...You're not listening. I suppose I used to talk over others at your age, as well.
...This may have been an enlightening conversation if you'd allow us to have it.
...At least you're not as xenophobic as I expected an Earth child to be. But manners still elude this planet.
...Thank you for the observation. I'm here to learn about Earth and the men on it--what are your reasons?
...And what is your reason for being here, a girl who presumably is more familiar with nude men?
Maybe for Earth women, this is a place to engage in cheap sex. For me, it's a chance to see men's bodies live for the first time...for scientific reasons.
...I have more of an excuse than most for being here beyond sex. I haven't seen a man naked in person--have you not, either?
You're awfully cynical about why I came here, Amy. Both Earth and men's anatomy are difficult topics to learn about on my homeworld.
...Well, you shouldn't look to a pirate for the most advanced technology Mejare offers. Still, I don't understand what you're looking for.
...What were you expecting? A bra made of shock-resistant nanomachines? That's research better spent on fighter ships.
...I'm just not sure what you're looking for, Amy. Computerized panties that monitor your hormone levels? It's unnecessary.
There are some aspects of society more in need of advancement than others, Amy. Our Dread fighters are very cutting edge--what are bras missing?
We always have choices to make. And sometimes you don't know what's best for yourself.
There's nothing to feel sad about. I accepted the job, and it's served both my ends and the crew's.
There's always a choice, even if it seems like they're being made for you. Besides...I think it's helped me grow as a person.
Part of our choices is how we handle what's out of our control. Our captain wanted what was best for me.
Our captain is a very old woman--a woman who never quite bought into Mejare's empire. She takes in any girl who will walk that path with her.
Our captain is many generations my senior. She's something of a Fama figure to all the girls we take in--well, mother figure.
Our captain has spent decades giving young girls like me a purpose. There's a reason we're called the Magno Family, after her.
Our captain is much older than the rest of us--we're mostly young thugs and refugees, like I was. She always keeps a cool head.
I'm just tempering your expectations...I don't expect you to share my interests.
...I enjoy piloting very much, Yuelia. I just don't expect others to, and would rather not impose.
...Thank you, Yuelia. I just don't mean to monopolize the conversation.
...I assume you're only making polite conversation, so I don't want to exhaust the subject.
...There are many moons for many planets. You'll have to be more specific.
...You're being quite vague about your whereabouts. There is no singular "moon."
...Do you mean this planet's one moon? If not, everything you've said is rather indeterminate.
"The" moon? ...It's strange that you would mention your view of my homeworld, yet be so reluctant to give more details.
And where is "Starlight Garden"? The name alone reveals little.
...That's a pleasant name, but it doesn't say much about where it's actually located.
..."Starlight." Does it exist far from any solar system, such as a comet?
"Starlight Garden"...that sounds like a name astronomers might give a star cluster. Are you located near any?
...Is that how you see the lives of the women on Mejare? Your home may come under attack one day, too.
A "fishbowl"? ...Our crew has met those who consider themselves casual observers of humanity's conflicts. It never lasts.
...So, you consider your homeworld safe enough to spend your time watching others struggle. You may be attacked next.
...So, you watch Mejare fend off attacks from both Tarak and Earth, and it's a source of entertainment. Neutrality is often tenuous at best.
A pirate for whom? There's many reasons a girl could find herself living a life like that...
You don't seem the type to associate with pirates, Yuelia...but I know they can take many forms. How did she get involved in that?
That's surprising to hear, Yuelia...but I don't know the politics of your world. How does she go about her piracy?
It's difficult to generalize exactly what a pirate's life is like. What does she do, and who does she work with?
...Why is that? Most women would consider it an uneviable position...
...No one's ever described being a pirate as "amazing" to me before. Each day is a fight for survival...what makes you say that?
..."Amazing"? Why do you say that? Pirates inherently go against civilians' ideas of role models...
...On Mejare, pirates are usually regarded either as violent anti-empire criminals. What makes us "amazing" in your eyes?
I agree. I didn't mean to imply that memories were worthless...but you can't let them hold you back, either.
No, I agree memories are important. I've struggled to strike a balance between remembering my family and moving on...
Memories are important--because they help us make choices for the future. I've had to learn not to just cling to them for their own sake.
I agree--and I've had to come to terms with my memories over time. They used to hold me back instead of propelling me forward.
I imagine because it looks like robotic eye implants at a glance. If it helps keep rookies in line, then I welcome it.
I've never asked anyone about it--probably because it looks mechanical, or like a face tattoo. Intimidation is valuable regardless.
I haven't questioned it--some fear factor is important for new recruits. I suppose it's just unusual--and they associate it with me glaring at them.
On a kinder woman's face, I'm sure it wouldn't scare them as much. But it's likely its proximity to my "icy eyes," as they say.
...My parents loved me very much. I just didn't appreciate them as much as I should have.
...I bonded with my parents. It's only now that I've realized it, is all.
...My family was in a very dark place when I last saw my parents. But I've grown to appreciate the bond we had then.
...It's not that. We had a bond, but I wasn't at the right age to understand that when they died. I've given it some thought since.
It's not wrong, but I don't see the fun in competing. I'd rather relax than seek out even more stress than usual and call it fun.
I just don't see a reason to conflate the two. I suppose women who live peaceful lives see competition as a thrill they lack...
Piloting is a stressful enough form of competition already. Maybe if I didn't have that, I wouldn't see fun as strictly a peaceful enterprise.
You're just mixing two activities that are inherently opposed. Perhaps if my lifestyle weren't so violent, I'd find more fun in competition...
I suppose that's the view one adopts when every day is a competition for resources. You're free to take other views.
If you enjoy competition, Yuelia, that's your business. I do, too--but it isn't fun. I compete every day just to survive.
A pilot's life consists of competing against an enemy you hate, Yuelia. It's only natural I'd feel that way.
Piracy is an ongoing competition for survival...so yes, I'm used to hating my opponents. Friendly competition exists to prepare for it.
...We have all of those devices, as well. Having that much information so close to one eye sounds like it'd cause headaches.
...You told me to explain myself, and I did. I'm not proud of my time on the streets...nor am I proud of my breasts.
...Neither my breasts nor my adolescence are sources of pride for me. I'm not interested in lying to you.
...You're quite arrogant to think I'd embellish my life just to appear tougher in front of you. As for my breasts, they're just smaller than I'd like...
I don't need to justify myself to you. My life is my own...and my breasts are smaller than I'd like.
...Wait. Do men...not menstruate? When is their seed viable to produce a child--always?
...Men don't have a period? If they're constantly producing viable seed, and the only way to flush it out is sex, then...no wonder they're intense.
...Men don't menstruate? No wonder they're so aggressive-- their bodies have a constant urge to reproduce!
...Thank you, Saki. This is only from simple cardio and strength training exercises, however--there's no need to flatter me.
...I keep myself fit enough to pilot effectively. "Really good shape" is excessive praise...but thank you.
...Thank you, Saki. It's difficult for me to put on muscle, but I've at least managed to tone my abs and backside. I could be built much better...
I would imagine that's because Earth has a vested interest in dehumanizing other planets' colonists, so they don't tell you about us.
Earth's own leadership is at the center of a conspiracy to attack colonists and harvest their organs. An informed populace might rebel.
Earth has carried out attacks on Mejare and other colonies. I thought they'd teach you we're inhuman, but perhaps the subject is simply erased.
I told you I'm human, Mary...but thank you. I'm actually not as well-endowed as the average Mejarian, but I'm sure you're talking about Earth...
..."Far from average." Compared to most Mejarians, I'm below average...compared to all human women, maybe not.
...You have a generous definition of "athlete," Erufuda. Much like your generous figure.
I do enjoy the support a sports bra provides, Erufuda...but you're probably in greater need of it than I am.
Well, then...it seems we can both take care of ourselves.
My crewmates can attest that I'm not so easily killed. Your fellow members of Lagoon Company would say the same about you, yes?
...Without more context, I suppose I have no choice but to overlook it.
...Hm. I often have to overlook slang our younger recruits use, simply assuming it's an insult.
..."Nintendo"? I don't understand, Moon. I do squats to maintain my backside's tone...it wasn't given to me, and that's what I like about it.
...As a Dread pilot, Moon, I sit down for a living. I fail to see how exercising to develop the butt's muscle is "not using it."
I hope my squat routine is paying off...I'm sure you can get everyone's attention by continuing to make a fool of yourself, Moon.
So, how does my butt look? ...I'm not going to spread it, Moon. And I'm sure you would spread yours regardless.
I hope my butt is toned properly...be quiet, Moon. I'll show what the table has earned the right to see.
...You can learn a lot from a woman's anus? From anyone else, I'd regard that as an interesting Earth saying...but not from you, Moon.
...Yes, you can, Moon. That's why I like it--girls are born with their breast size, but a toned butt is something any woman can work for.
...Mmgh. There's something special about peeling that suit off at night...is something wrong, Komi-san?
It's good that stripping actually brings me some comfort. You can see how I sweat in that suit...what is it, Komi-san?
Mmh...here I am, exposed. ...Thank you, Komi. My Oma didn't have particularly large breasts, either...
I'm aware they don't impress...there's no need for flattery, Komi. I seem to take after my Oma, who wasn't well-endowed herself...
...I'm sure your position has its unique challenges. I was a child celebrity myself.
...I can't claim to understand what that's like, exactly, but I did make many media appearances as a girl...
...Yes, I think we're at an agreement. As long as you don't intend to "lay hands" on me.
..."Shapely knockers." I appreciate that, but you should expect a drop kick if you lay hands on them.
My pilots respect both me and the seriousness of our situation. Do not assume everyone is as lazy as you are.
If a pilot of mine neglects her fitness, it is with the understanding that it could get herself or a crewmate killed.
If my pilots do not fear the danger a lack of combat readiness presents, they certainly fear me dressing them down in public.
I consider that a compliment. I do my best to give my pilots sound fitness advice, knowing how easily a woman can gain weight.
I had to gain muscle the hard way before I joined our crew. The least I could do is act as my team members' personal trainer.
...In other words, you dabble in different exercise types to avoid making a concerted effort. You can't achieve meaningful results like that.
...The fact you named social connections over the number of sets shows the failure of your approach. Pick one of those and stick with it.
...No, it won't be. This ring is my sidearm.
...It won't. This ring is a weapon, not jewelry.
...No, I won't be counting my laser ring. It's for self-defense.
...I see. Whatever the case, I'm glad to have quickly earned a man's respect.
...I'm glad women are included in your enterprises, then. I'd like to think I've earned the respect of my male crewmates in the same way.
...So "brawling" is more of an Earth source of pride than a male one. I hope your culture isn't dominated by violence.
...So this is really a matter of Earth glorifying fighting above all else.
...I didn't expect Earth's culture to place such heavy emphasis on fighting. This was where my ancestors engineered spacecrafts.
...Anyone can brawl, but I'm not sure why they should. I'm surprised the planet that introduced space travel would be a warrior culture.
...Why not carry a sidearm for those situations? It would be just as foolish to try to pilot my Dread in an enclosed space.
You can't always expect to operate at optimal range. They may not be as flashy, but small arms are practical for that situation.
Tarot cards...is this woman a priestess? Our captain has a set of those.
...Tarot cards are a superstitious tool, not weaponry. Our captain used to be a priestess, and I believe she has a set.
...I have crewmates who would describe me in as precisely the opposite.
...That sounds like the inverse of my reputation.
...Your colleague is a cactus. I can only assume that's the nickname of a robot assistant model.
...I see. What is the technical name of the robot model "Cactus" refers to?
...Mejarians are the women from my homeworld. My opinion of men was steadily improving until I met one who'd bring explosives into a bar.
...Mejarians, who I am one of. It was part of my identity to hate men...your reckless handling of explosives isn't helping.
...Sometimes I envy men's ability to get excited about warfare.
...Even the most belligerent women I know usually approach fighting from a place of anger. Men like you seem excited to battle.
...I'm starting to understand how Earth could be so convinced of its own superiority. Fighting is tradition...
...So, fighting is integral to Earth's way of life. Perhaps it only developed space travel in the name of conquest.
They were enemy combatants, on top of being women's sworn enemy. They soon proved their usefulness and were promoted to crew members.
...If it makes you feel better, those men are now valued crewmates. We took them prisoner in the first place because they were enemy soldiers.
...That comparison would apply if everyone with your skin color formed an enemy colony and declared war on us.
...They're prisoners of war, and just as likely to capture women if we were in their position. Skin color is irrelevant.
They weren't civilians, they were soldiers. Luckily, we're pirates--Mejarian imperials would've executed them.
...You're joking, but that sounds like the kind of reckless plan the man in my squadron might come up with. In his Vanguard, that is.
...Using a close-range explosion to propel oneself to safety is exactly the kind of thing my male pilot might suggest. I don't think he'd try that outside his mech.
...I fail to see how a fight can be friendly if combatants are wielding rocket launchers.
...I imagine you don't bring explosives to your friendly encounters.
...Surely it's not a pastime for you to fire rockets at your colleagues.
...I don't understand what you define as a pastime. Unless you have nonlethal rockets.
...I have a few crewmates myself who'd jump at the chance for combat.
...I have a subordinate pilot who might be interested in utilizing her gun collection. Our commander enjoys fighting, too--she prefers a whip.
That doesn't sound sustainable. Energy drinks are empty calories.
Energy drinks are very unhealthy. You should advise her to at least drink coffee if she needs a stimulant.
Energy drinks are meant to be addictive. You should help her kick that habit.
...So, they have energy drinks on Earth, too. Mejare's are nothing but unhealthy mixtures of sugar and caffeine.
...I can only be critical of energy drinks when I drink coffee. Still, you shouldn't take after her.
Energy drinks aren't nutritious in the slightest. If your caffeine has to come from somewhere, I recommend coffee...
In a suit like mine, yes. You'd need one tailored for your body. Even then, men lack the smooth curves needed for fluidity...
Well, you couldn't fit in mine. But for a woman's smoother body, it's quite comfortable and elastic...
I'll be happy to discuss bodysuit fashion with her without suggesting we stick men inside them.
I have no desire to put that notion in her head. Men seem better suited for the baggy clothes I see them wearing.
All the men I know do prefer loose-fitting clothing. I figured it was to give that tube between your legs some breathing room.
...Is that a euphemism for putting your tube-organ in loose clothes? I can only imagine what a tight suit would do that thing.
Hm. Women would probably find it funny to see each other in frumpy, unflattering clothing...
A woman dressing in a loose outfit would probably be mocked in the same way, as if she's ashamed of her figure.
Perhaps if a man were fit enough, he could pull it off...we do have the same basic anatomy.
It may not be inherently funny. A man with enough muscles to fill it out might make a suit look quite good, actually...
It's funny how it took men's influence for me to come here at all...to a planet full of men influencing women.
To think I never would have considered coming here without men entering my life...you have a curious effect on women.
I mean Mejare's culture is cut off from Earth's, as are most other colonies. So our idea of how names should be used may be old-fashioned to you.
Mejare and other extraterrestial colonies have since lost contact with Earth and each other. That may have led to some cultural inertia, including names.
...That's good, at least. It doesn't sound very masculine...
...I thought not. It's a feminine name...there's no harsh sounds in it.
...So, she relies on stimulants to stay active. I enjoy coffee myself, but it's not how I manage to fly...
...Packed with sugar, you mean. It's calories without any nutrition to speak of.
...If by power, you mean caffeine. They're good for a quick high and little else--if coffee is too bitter for you.
...No, I think you'd just rip it before that happens. It's elastic enough for me to move, but a man's body would push it over the edge.
My flightsuit's material actually has a fair bit of give to it for ease of movement. Still, you might tear it rather than suffocating...
Either that, or it'd stretch out to accommodate you, however barely. The man in my Dread team is so short, he could wear it like rags...
...Well, I have noticed men don't seem to pack fat onto their backsides. Your hips aren't as wide, either. It's only natural.
...Would you rather I said your butt was large? The more fat on it, the more you'd resemble a woman...
...My eyepiece is only an "artifact" of the company that made it. It's just a fashion prototype.
...You won't gain much historical insight from my eyepiece. Even my crewmates find it peculiar.
...It's hard to say. I came here to learn more about men and women's coexistence.
...I know very little of Earth's society. I was hoping I could learn from your perspective on the matter, actually.
...Outside of this game, my exposure to Earth men and women together is from old Christmas tapes. I'd hoped to speak with you on the matter.
...I don't know much about this planet's society, actually. Men and women form couples and have children...that's about it. You seem like a good source of information.
...Thank you. I don't hear that a lot...you're pleasant company yourself.
...That's not something my crewmates often tell me. I think they might be afraid to...I'm enjoying your company, as well.
I don't attend parties.
I avoid them. My crewmates have tried to throw me surprise birthday parties, to no success.
Mejare was settled around a hundred years ago, but I can forgive your ignorance. Apparently Earth has hidden information about its colonies.
Earth has no interest in humanizing its colonists, so I don't blame you for not knowing about Mejare. It's only a few generations old, anyway.
It's not your fault. Mejare and Tarak weren't aware of any other colonies until recently, either--I believe that's by Earth's design.
I wouldn't have admitted I'm a pirate in the first place if this were an attack.
Why would I admit that in the first place if I were here to raid this place? We don't operate on negotiation and misdirection.
My admission of being a pirate should have been proof enough. The Magno Family operates on surprise attacks and quick withdrawals.
...I'm sorry to disappoint, Orendi. I have suffered injuries before--cuts, a ruptured spleen, and a fractured femur, among others. But they were treated quickly.
...I'm very fortunate to not have suffered injuries on that level, Orendi--I know women who have. Luckily, quick treatment can fix most damage.
...I'm sorry if this place lacks medical resources, Orendi. Piloting is dangerous, but we can usually treat all but the most grisly injuries.
People come up to you and poke your body? I suppose we tend to mistreat robots ourselves--but none of our robots look and act as human as you do.
...Do people really just invade your personal space? Humans do treat robots as tools, but no robot as human as you exists on Mejare...
...Maybe your artist saw beauty in imperfection. Flaws are what make humans interesting--and worrying about one's flaws is very human.
...No woman is perfect. Maybe your artist wanted to capture that. Worrying about your flaws, meanwhile... that's a human trait.
I was part of that upper class at first. My parents were contracted to help mitigate the issue. But they didn't prove immune to those same influences...
I'm not blameless. My family was rich, and they helped design those very living systems. I don't know how deep the corruption ran.
I'm lucky to have been accepted by the pirates at all. My family was involved in the design of those living systems, and I was the poster girl.
I wasn't an average citizen before that. My parents were famous contributors to the project. They told me they meant well, but I'll never know for sure.
...Do you mean my backside, Pyrrha? Where I'm from, women tend to prefer breasts. If men are the opposite...well, I'm not sure I want them behind me.
So...men prefer women's butts, Pyrrha? I'm not sure I want their attention, especially with my back turned...
If it's anywhere near our projected course, then perhaps we'll see Gamindustri for ourselves. From one colonist to another, Earth's Harvester fleet is hostile and active.
If the Nirvana's crew encounters Gamindustri en route to Mejare, then we'll investigate it. I suggest you ready your defenses in case of an Earth attack.
Pirates have no need for money. Whatever we find on a raid, it goes to our collective treasury.
Money is irrelevant to me now. For doing my duty as a pilot, I'm given a bed and a meal ticket.
...Thank you, Sayaka. My homeworld actually sexualizes women's breasts more than their backsides.
Thank you, Sayaka. I do my best to keep it toned. But women falling in love isn't too relevant--Mejare celebrates breasts more than backsides.
I'm surprised you settled on a planet with such dangerous wildlife. We haven't encountered any alien beings at all.
Why would you colonize a planet with such aggressive fauna? It's rare enough to encounter alien life forms in the first place.
...I'm not sure as to the nature of this place myself. In any case, I believe Earth humans reached genetic stagnation and failed to maintain their environment after seveal catastrophes.

...Whether or not this place is in a time-space anomaly, I can't say. What we know of Earth in my time is that it suffered accidents after sending out frontier ships, leaving its people unable to reproduce.
...Is something wrong, Komi? This whole place feels like some strange anomaly in spacetime--I wouldn't assume that this Earth will become the one I know.
...You look concerned. You shouldn't take what I say as the certain future of this Earth--the whole nature of this place is hard to judge.
Their main target has first been our ship, which means our crew has been put on the defensive. We used to plan out raids, but now we're on constant alert to scramble.
It's not quite warfare yet--they're just on their way to Mejare, as we are. But it means our ship is alone in fending off random attacks. It's a role reversal for pirates like us.
...No, it isn't. If this planet's moon has suffered damage that great, it's no wonder Earth eventually lost its gravitational pull over it.
It'd take incredible energy to split a planet's moon into fragments. I've never seen one in that state, but it would explain how Earth fell into environmental ruin.
No, I don't think so. This place is mysterious in more ways than just the primitive appearance--it might even be some kind of spacetime anomaly.
I'm not sure if time travel is actually involved--it's just my best guess for why Earth appears as it does here, centuries old. In any case, it wasn't my doing.
It's probably a carryover from our Earth ancestors. At least it's a choice for the couple to make instead of forced upon you by your sex.
Mejarians are all descended from Earth women, so it's probably just tradition. Personality seems like a better factor to decide people's roles than their sex.
...There are a lot of things I used to regret. But I've started to accept who I've become and appreciate the people I've met.
...Regretting my whole life is foolish. I've come to enjoy being a pilot on our crew, and staying in school just wouldn't have been that simple.
...No. It's foolish to regret that kind of thing--I'd never become the person I am now, or met my crewmates, or explored the galaxy.
I feel the same way about our crew. It's strange--we used to be a lot less friendly with each other before the men came aboard.
Our crew has been getting along a lot better ourselves. Maybe it's from fighting our new enemy, or maybe we just see more similarities in each other now that men are around.
I remember our crew feeling a lot more like strangers a year ago. Maybe the men have brought us together as women, just as the journey brought us together with them.
There are times when I'm not working, but I use those to stay fit or rest at the spa. It's improper for everyone to relax at once, so I volunteer to scout ahead.
I guess it's wrong to say I have no breaks at all--I keep a workout routine and decompress in our jacuzzi. But the best use of my time is as a scout, especially when the others are off guard.
...I'm not sure I've ever felt something was perfect. I think of that as my bad habit, actually--not being able to appreciate things.
...Have you ever felt that way about something? I could always find a flaw, even when I was little-- pessimism is a bad habit of mine.
...That was my goal in coming here. I hope to learn more about Earth's culture, including "dicks."
...I would be happy to share details of Mejare's culture in return for those of Earth. For instance, "dicks."
...I assume "dick" means a man. Men are part of Earth's culture, so I would appreciate information on both.
Most colonies we've found are at least still alive. For some, we're far too late, and the only thing there is traps left behind for us.
We've usually managed to save those we find from further attacks. Other times they're just abandoned stations, or traps left by the enemy.

condition.saying: But then again, neither are you

case.state: ...I haven't seen that sort of pirate depicted. That might be exclusive to Earth's culture.
...That image of a pirate might exist only on Earth. Mejare's idea of one looks a lot like me, just dirtier and more muscular.

condition.saying: It makes you look a lot less intimidating

case.state: This is just to show my authority. We normally wear our spacesuits and masks when we're trying to intimidate men.
If my wing commander's armor is intimidating, you'd probably be frightened by the sight of me in a raid suit and mask--what little you could see through the antiseptic spray.
It depends on the topic. Any discussion of men, history, or the government makes a classroom go quiet.
There are military schools where one can have her soul crushed. I went to a civilian school, which are normally relaxed unless we bring up men and Mejare's history with them.
Actually, it's the former in most classes. When girls get a little older, they introduce us to men and how the imperial army protects us from them. That topic is always serious.
...Thank you. It's unlikely we'll get involved in a planet's internal politics.
...I appreciate the compliment. It's true we've been intervening for other planets recently, but it's been against foreign enemies.
...Money isn't any use to us. You should look elsewhere.
...We only steal to survive, not to make money. We won't risk a conflict for that.
...For your information, the men's planet is hardly a paradise itself. You know nothing about my home beyond what I've told you.
...I may be opposed to its government, but I still grew up there. I don't appreciate you calling my home a disaster waiting to happen.
...I don't mean to compare you to the Earthlings I know. It makes sense that you'd be more humane--you live on an Earth that can still support humanity.
The Earth of my time can't sustain human life. It's not surprising that their sense of humanity would follow.
...I do know him the best of the three. We've come to respect each other...in fact, he's been my co-pilot at times.
We've learned to get along. We both jump to action, so we've butted heads...I've had to share a cockpit with him, even.
Our energy core has a will of its own, and it only accepts his commands. He's cowardly, but...he does always seem to come through in the end.
...He doesn't have much confidence in himself, but our ship's core seems to believe in him. It acts like a living thing at times.
He takes his work seriously--I think the chance to study women's bodies interests him. I do appreciate how he's become a mentor for our nurse in training.
We're not working with our full forces. He's helped train our young nurse...I recall him saying that our ship is the first time he's felt stimulated by his work.
Well, isn't that sweet. You remind me of a short, excitable pain-in-the-neck man I work with.
Funny. I would say the same thing about Hibiki, who shares your personality...and genitalia, presumably.
I try to be a reliable leader to my pilots, so apparently it's a good disposition to have.
At least you care about her. I wasn't sure men were capable of those sorts of feelings.
A pain in the neck, am I? The feeling's mutual.
Its purpose...is to remember my Oma by. But don't worry about that.
...It has no function, but it does have a purpose. It's a gift from my Oma...nothing to dwell on.
...My Oma gave it to me before she died. That's its purpose...but I'll drop the subject.
A purpose...well, a memento is a purpose. A gift from my late Oma...but I won't bring things down.
I'll leave the other Earthlings at this table to tell me of your many great deeds. Magic should have made those easy.
I would expect a woman with magical powers to be famous, but Earth has continued to surprise me.
It would seem strange for a woman with magical powers to not gain a following. Where are your legions of fans?
I haven't seen the media hounding you for being such a well-known magician. Not that I would wish that on you...
I wouldn't expect an inhuman monstrosity to understand family mementos.
...Do you have a family, Beatrix? Or were you constructed in a factory in a vain attempt to understand human emotions?
It was a family gift. I assume you don't yet have the programming to understand why a human woman might cherish that.
My family gave it to me. Do you have the programming to understand families, Beatrix?
Life form? I'm a woman, the same as you. I should've expected an Earth child to petulant and xenophobic.
Mejarian women are no less human than Earth ones. I see Earth teaches its children to be xenophobic bigots.
...Life form? I don't need to justify my humanity to a petulant Earth child.
Perhaps if you listened to others instead of making snide comments, you'd realize I'm every bit the human woman you are.
Eyepatch? It was a gift from my Oma. It means a lot to me.
Red eyes? Sounds like a fearsome woman.
...Unlike blue hair, red eyes are not common on Mejare. Now I don't know how you confused us.
Just an honest mistake, I'm sure. Meia Gisborn, pleased to meet you.
Just an honest mistake, I'm sure. I'm from Mejare...I assume this "Ayanami Rei" is an Earth woman.
Mejare would have you believe that, yes. But they would also have you believe that men want to feast on your organs.
Call us villains if you want, but Mejare and Tarak both deserve piracy.
I don't have glowing opinions of Earth's heroics, either.
Oh, I've lived and worked with a few men at this point...but this is a chance to learn about their biology.
Well, I know a few men now...but I was hoping this place would teach me about their anatomy.
...My interest in men is purely scientific. I know they're tolerable to live around already...
...I just came here at my crewmate's insistence. We have a few men on board...I figured learning about their bodies would be useful.
...You're unusually polite for a man. It must be a soldier's discipline.
Military service must instill some politeness in men. Duero and Bart are the same way...I wish I could say the same for Hibiki.
How very considerate of you. Maybe men aren't animals...if you train them to be soldiers.
...Thank you. Between you and the cadets I know, it seems men make more upstanding soldiers than women do.
I don't need a man's approval to do as I please...but I do appreciate a man's challenge.
I'll do as I please with or without a man's consent. To me, you're still the enemy.
Of course. Perhaps Earth women seek men's approval for their actions...I seek to defeat you.
And the same to you. Don't think being complimentary will make me forget you're a man--and my opponent.
Actually, Mejarians crave romance and intimacy. It must be men's influence that makes you want toys.
I'm afraid most Mejarians prefer the feel of skin. I think men have made you dependent on penetration.
We're encouraged to form families and be nuturing Famas on Mejare, so I'm not sure we can deliver the roughness men have given you.
I understand men are rough with you...so it makes sense you want intensity. But Mejarian culture likes romance.
It's my profession as a Mejarian pirate to make men surrender, actually. I think you may be only describing yourself.
Men on Tarak surrender all the time, actually. Clearly you don't speak for your entire sex.
Is that so? Strange how we've taken men prisoner, then...Earth men must be a more resilient race.
Never surrendering is a good way for a man to receive numerous blast wounds. You might find yourself trying it soon.
I don't...I think my Oma's company made them, but they never finalized it.
I'm sorry. I've never even seen another one...so I can't help there.
You're better off just practicing. I don't know where my Oma got it from.
It's the only one of its kind I know of. That's why it's a good memento...
That's quite the blanket statement about Earthlings... one that's contradicted by their attempts to kill us.
The only thing Earthlings have proven honest about is their plans to harvest our organs.
My main impression of Earth is that it considers its colonies subhuman organ farms, actually.
I've spent the last year fighting off fleets of Earth's Harvest cubes. Forgive my doubts about your "honesty."
You shouldn't insult people you've just met. You really are like Hibiki.
In general, if a woman is wearing something, it means a lot to her.
Don't insult the clothing of others without knowing them first.
For a girl who came here armed to the teeth, you're very friendly.
It's strange to see an armed girl be so cheerful...I'm almost envious.
So upbeat for a girl carrying weapons...I'm not sure whether to see you as a threat.
A girl who seems to fight for a living, yet is perfectly cheerful. You remind me of Dita, one of my subordinates...
I do appreicate it when women take themselves seriously. She must be your leader.
Is "Number Three" your group's leader? A serious woman is the best suited for the job.
Every functioning group needs a woman who takes herself seriously. I imagine she manages your affairs?
Perhaps I'd get along with "Number Three," then. Does she take command when the rest of you lose focus?
The rest of my bodysuit.
If it's jiggling you want, my subordinate Barnette is the woman for you. She has bigger breasts and less support for them.
I haven't so much been out in space as I just live there.
Jiggling? I don't have the breasts for that...
I see...the Paksis actually feeds off of our emotions. As for our lives, Earth's goal is to harvest our organs...
Hmm. That's not unlike how Earthlings keep themselves alive--by taking our organs for themselves. Perhaps they power Expsheres with them...
The Paksis doesn't feed off of our lives, but it does draw from our emotions. Perhaps Earth uses our harvested organs for "Exspheres."
As a resident of one of Earth's organ-harvesting colonies, I understand your concerns with human lives powering technology.
...I'm so confused. 9000 what? Are you even listening to me?
Over 9000 what? Measurements need units. Don't they teach you that in school?
...Are you still talking to me, Sola? 9000 units of...what, exactly?
...Is this what Earth girls do to foreigners? Intentionally confuse them? What units am I measuring?
...I'd argue its significance, Spooky, but you've lost the most significant possession of all.
...Well, when a ghost tells you something is insignificant, perhaps it holds water.
...I can't argue how important my eyepiece is to a woman who's lost her own life.
...And you seem rather unperturbed by being dead. Maybe you have a point.
Not everyone has to be serious. It's just probably better for the squadron if I am...
I have to be serious...I'm a leader. But you're fine the way you are, I'm sure.
I'm not a role model. I try to be, but I make too many mistakes...
It's not a costume, it's armor. But you're right, I need it for shocks while flying.
Well, technically it exists for shocks, but it's more of a symbol of rank...only a few of my pilots wear something like it.
...I'm not even sure how to respond to that. Are large breasts looked down upon on Earth?
...Right. I see Mejare and Earth differ wildly on breast size preferences.
...I'll be honest, Zizou, I've never seen a grown woman with breasts as small as yours. It must be a cultural preference.
...I wasn't aware Earthlings preferred small breasts. I hope you produce enough milk to feed your children.
...Is that an example of the android's trademark evasion?
As in, evading the subject?
I see. Good job evading the conversation.
...Speaking of evasion, yes, let's continue playing.
I'm glad you're curious. I might have some questions of my own about Earth...if you're willing to answer.
Earth is just as fascinating to me as Mejare is to you...I may have my own questions.
...Are you willing to talk about this planet? If so, I'll say more on Mejare...
Mejare isn't perfect, Daria, but I'm willing to satisfy your curiosity...if you'll indulge me when I ask about Earth.
Well, I don't do it for fun.
A lot of women's lives are in my hands when I pilot. I take it seriously.
...I'm glad you appreciate it.
...Well, it's nice to have a fan. Thank you.
Funny. Normally being a pilot creates enemies for me.
...I'm not from this planet, Gwen. Your whole line of thinking is wrong.
...Gwen, I was raised to believe men were violent animals. Start your assumptions from there.
...Mejare is a planet of all women. It was settled for that purpose. You don't need to make assumptions.
...If you're done trying to figure out the Mejarian for yourself, you could just ask me.
...Feel free to explain what a Trigger is, too.
...I don't think practice will get me anywhere until I learn what a "Trigger" is.
If you're handing out free weaponry, our crew is always in need of supplies...but I seriously doubt you're so generous.
My crewmates' attitudes negate the need for armor, too...or so they think.
"Negates the need for armor"? ...You have my attention, though we've been fooled before by strange men offering weaponry.
...If anything you're saying is true, you're quite the interesting specimen. Particularly for being so casual about weapons and war.
If you have any questions about Mejare, Jotaro, I seem to have become its cultural envoy.
It seems I've become Mejare's ambassador to Earth in this game. If you're confused about us, fire away.
I still have some work to get done, but I'll answer any questions you have about Mejare...I understand men and women are inseperable here.
Yes...to an Earth man, I suppose women existing on their own must be a bizarre idea. Don't be afraid to ask.
I don't mind answering questions about Mejare...it might help me learn about Earth. And men.
...Actually, yes, it can. My Dread and a male Vanguard can form an entirely new vessel when combined...
Funnily enough, yes. A Vandread is formed from a female Dread and a male Vanguard...yes, I've heard what that resembles.
I don't know about manly passion, but combining mechs does require a male ship called a Vanguard. So take that victory.
Combining ships is the reason for our success, actually. We've kept the men around because of the need to fuse with male Vanguards, among other things...
You are the closest to alien life we've discovered so far.

A genetic hybrid of woman and sheep would qualify as alien life more than I would.
If you're searching for alien life, I suggest you start with yourself.
...I think you may be mistaken, Miko. The Nirvana is a spaceship.
...Miko, the Nirvana is a spaceship, not a boat. So I wouldn't be a sailor, or encounter these things.
...The Nirvana is a spaceship, Miko. ...You're not listening.
I'm happy for your ally Futo, but boats and spaceships aren't comparable.
What's that supposed to mean? Does she wear the same suit underneath armor? ...Part of me wants to meet her now.
Feel free to list every similarity with this "Rei," Misato. You've got me curious now.
This "Rei" sounds like a woman I'd get along with. Send her over here next time.
It's a rare woman that people consider similar to me...in my experience. Now I want to meet this "Rei" of yours.
Oh, our quartermaster is a tall woman named Gascogne--whom I respect very much. I'd introduce you to her if you'd like.

Gascogne, our quartermaster, gave that armor to me quite a while ago...and she'd love to talk to you over poker.
Oh, our quartermaster Gascogne loves poker even more than I do. Play a game with her, and she'll tell you all about our armor...
Made of? I'm not sure...I'm more concerned with the protection it provides, mostly from Mejarian laser rings.
I don't know...it's standard issue, and was given to me when I took command of my Dread squadron.
It's not much as battle armor...mostly there for protection during flight. Not sure about the materials, either.

Mejare has more than a few bodysuited idol groups. But they all sing about the dangers of men.
I'm not completely unfamiliar with idols, but Mejare's mostly sing about the evil male hordes of Tarak. Some in bodysuits.
Bodysuit are standard Mejarian fashion. What makes it "retro"? Idols wear them all the time as they warn us about men.

Your frame is rather small for it, but it might be amusing.

You're much better off staying in school than idolizing pirates. It wouldn't fit you anyway...

...I've never considered myself special, especially not by how I was born.
Born with? A woman's worth isn't a matter of the circumstances of her birth.
Born with? I put more stock in what women do with their lives than in how their lives begin.
Being a pirate teaches you that most people aren't very special, actually.
I'm a woman like any other. Perhaps these "Quirks" are exclusive to Earth...using the harvested organs of its colonies.

Excellent show of confidence.

Have you seen someone die before? ...Never mind. Can you fix machines with your magic?

I do wonder how your magic might benefit you as a pilot...or an engineer. Do you mind blood?
I wish I still had your innocence. Dita's held onto it somehow...could your magic make the ship run better?
What's wrong with my underwear? Haven't you been with women before?
You're talking like you've never been with a woman. I thought Earth men and women were all over each other.
Surely an Earth man has seen women naked before. Underwear should be no issue for you.
How ironic. An Earth woman sees Mejarians the same as men from Tarak do...monsters.
Apparently even young Earth girls think we're hideous creatures. Normally we get that from Tarakkian men.
I have plenty of experience being treated as a scaly monster. That's how Tarak, the planet of men, sees us.
That's not an opinion unique to Earth. Tarak, the male colony, raises its men to think the same thing about us.
I have no issue with standing in my underwear, Elaine. It's quite supportive.
Uncomfortable with your body, Elaine? I happen to like my underwear.
